    Hydroxypyridinone-Based Iron Chelators with Broad-Ranging Biological Activities

    • Xiaoying Jiang
      Xiaoying Jiang
      Collaborative Innovation Centre of Yangtze River Delta Region Green Pharmaceuticals, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, 310014, P.R. China
      More by Xiaoying Jiang
      View Biography

    Abstract

    Iron plays an essential role in all living cells because of its unique chemical properties. It is also the most abundant trace element in mammals. However, when iron is present in excess or inappropriately located, it becomes toxic. Excess iron can become involved in free radical formation, resulting in oxidative stress and cellular damage. Iron chelators are used to treat serious pathological disorders associated with systemic iron overload. Hydroxypyridinones stand out for their outstanding chelation properties, including high selectivity for Fe3+ in the biological environment, ease of derivatization, and good biocompatibility. Herein, we overview the potential for multifunctional hydroxypyridinone-based chelators to be used as therapeutic agents against a wide range of diseases associated either with systemic or local elevated iron levels.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Iron is a vital metal for all life and is involved in a wide variety of biological events. It is essential for DNA synthesis and repair, energy production, myelination, transport of oxygen, the functioning of numerous enzymes, neurotransmitter synthesis, host defense, and cell signaling processes.(1) There are about 400 iron-dependent enzymes in the human, involving such binding sites on heme, iron–sulfur clusters, and highly polar oxygen atoms.(2) However, although iron is necessary for the normal function of every form of life, it is toxic when it is present in excess or inappropriately placed. In the presence of oxygen, “loosely bound” iron is able to redox cycle between the Fe(II) and Fe(III), producing highly reactive oxygen free radicals, resulting in peroxidative damage of tissues.(3) As a result of this potential toxicity, the iron levels are strictly controlled in all living forms, and thus there is little chance of free radical-generating reactions being catalyzed by the presence of iron.
    In primates, there is no active mechanism of iron elimination. Iron homeostasis is mainly achieved by regulating the intestinal absorption of iron and the efficient recycling of erythrocyte-derived iron.(4,5) Under certain pathological conditions, systemic or local iron overload can occur, leading to free radical-mediated tissue/organ damage and cell death.(6) Local elevated iron levels are associated with many diseases, particularly neurodegenerative diseases.(2,3) In the presence of inappropriately high iron levels, either systemic or local, it is important to selectively remove excess iron using iron chelators. Among the various forms of iron chelators, hydroxypyridinones (HPOs) stand out for their high and relatively specific iron chelation properties. Indeed, HPOs provide an excellent scaffold, which is capable of generating a wide range of chemical structures, associated with different biological actions.

    1.1. Iron Distribution in the Normal Human Body

    Iron is one of the most abundant trace elements in living organisms, and the content in the normal human body is approximately 3–5 g (40–50 mg/kg).(7) The absorption, storage, utilization, and secretion of iron are tightly controlled in mammalian cells (Figure 1A).(8−10) The absorption of iron in mammals is mainly through the absorption of Fe2+ and its subsequent oxidation to Fe3+ by ferroxidases (hephaestin (HEPE) and ceruloplasmin (CP)) and subsequently transfer to transferrin (TF). TF enters the endosome of those cells that express a transferrin receptor (TFR), for instance, TFR1-mediated endocytosis.(8,11,12) Fe3+ is released from TF, reduced by ferriductase, and enters the labile iron pool (LIP) via the divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).(13)
    Senescent red blood cells (RBCs) are absorbed by phagocytosis in cells of the reticuloendothelial system, providing heme to phagolysosomes.(14,15) Other heme forms, such as heme-hemopexin (HPX) and hemoglobin (HB)-haptoglobin (HP), are absorbed by specific receptors and result in the import of heme into macrophages. The heme is then degraded by heme oxygenase 1 (HMOX1).(8,14,15)
    Iron is taken up from the blood by cells utilizing several transport proteins. The iron enters the LIP, which serves as a medium for utilization, storage, and export of iron. In most cells, iron in LIP is utilized for synthesizing iron proteins and enzymes. In erythroid cells, iron is mainly delivered to the mitochondria for the synthesis of heme and the biogenesis of iron–sulfur clusters (ISCs).(13) Excess LIP iron is incorporated and stored in ferritin.(16−18) Iron that is not utilized or stored will be exported from cells via ferroportin (FPN).(8)
    Iron homeostasis is regulated at both the cellular level and the tissue level. At the cellular level, iron is primarily post-transcriptional regulated by the iron-responsive element/iron regulatory protein (IRE/IRP) system. The interactions of IRE/IRP regulate the expression of the mRNAs encoding proteins, which are involved in iron absorption, storage, utilization, and export for iron homeostasis.(19) At the systemic tissue level, iron homeostasis is mainly regulated by the iron sensor hepcidin encoded by the HAMP gene. Hepcidin, a peptide hormone produced by the liver in response to iron and inflammation, forms a negative feedback regulation of iron uptake by binding the iron exporter FPN.(2) Hepcidin can reduce the expression of FPN, and so reduce intracellular iron excretion, such that iron is retained within the absorption and reticuloendothelial cells.(11) Elevated levels of plasma iron or inflammation will stimulate the transcription of hepcidin mRNA in hepatic tissues, thereby reducing iron uptake in duodenal enterocytes and the mobilization of iron storage. When plasma iron is decreased as in the case of anemia, transcription of hepcidin is inhibited, which effectively increases the rate of iron absorption from the intestine.

    1.2. Influence of Elevated Levels of Iron

    A redox cycle between Fe2+ and Fe3+ can be initiated with loosely bound iron in the presence of oxygen, producing reactive oxygen species (ROS) via the Fenton reaction.(20) The production of ROS is controlled by defensive antioxidant systems including catalase, superoxide dismutase (SOD), and glutathione peroxidase (GPX) (Figure 1B). However, this normally effective protective defense system can be overrun in the presence of iron overload. Excess iron can lead to the saturation of transferrin, which is accompanied by an increase of non-transferrin-bound iron (NTBI, Fe3+). NTBI can be transported into inappropriate cells via various carries proteins, e.g., solute carrier family 39 members ZIP8 and ZIP14.(21−24) The resulting elevated iron levels lead to free radical-mediated tissue/organ damage and cell death.(25)
    Elevated levels of iron are associated with the occurrence and development of many diseases, such as neurodegenerative diseases (NDDs), cancer, and infections.(11,26) Iron overload can also promote oxidative stress to initiate nerve cell damage, promote pathogen competition for iron to aggravate infection, and cause genetic mutations that accelerate the formation of cancer cells with a high iron requirements.(27−34)

    1.3. Classification of Iron(III) Chelators

    Metal selectivity is an important factor for clinically useful iron chelators. In theory, chelators can be designed as either iron(II)- or iron(III)-selective chelators. However, it is difficult to design nontoxic iron(II) chelators due to their low selectivity, leading to the removal of biologically important bivalent metals (Cu2+ and Zn2+). Iron(III)-selective chelators are preferable as most trivalent metals (e.g., Al3+, In3+, and Ga3+) are not present in living cells.(35) High-affinity iron(III) chelators can also chelate iron(II), the resulting complexes being rapidly autoxidized to form the corresponding iron(III) complexes.(36) Thus, iron(III) chelators with high selectivity and affinity make useful therapeutic agents.
    According to the theory of hard and soft acids and bases, Fe2+ has a low charge density and prefers chelators containing “softer” donor atoms (aromatic N-containing ligands). In contrast, Fe3+ has five electrons in the 3d orbital, possessing a stable semifilled structure with a high charge density. Thus, Fe3+ is classified as a “hard” Lewis acid, which can form most stable complexes with “hard” ligands (charged O-containing ligands).(36) The high spin Fe3+ coordinates with six donor atoms of the ligands to form a complex in an octahedral manner,(37) and the chelator can be classified as hexadentate, tridentate, and bidentate ligand according to the number of donor atoms (Figure 2).(36,38)
    The pFe3+ value is a useful parameter for assessing the affinity of ligands to Fe3+ under biological conditions (pFe3+ = −log[Fe3+] when [Fe3+]total = 10–6 M and [ligand]total = 10–5 M at pH 7.4). The higher the pFe3+ value, the greater the affinity for Fe3+.(39) A value greater than 20 is generally considered to be suitable for iron scavenging properties under biological conditions.
    Chelators that bind both Fe3+ and Fe2+ are capable of redox cycling, leading to the production of ROS and increased toxicity. The high selectivity of chelators for Fe3+ over Fe2+ results in extremely low redox potentials, and iron complexes with redox potentials below −200 mV render redox cycling under biological conditions unlikely.(38) Therefore, a good chelator should have a high selectivity and affinity for Fe3+ and possess a low redox potential (typically < −400 mv), which cannot be reduced under biological conditions.

    1.3.1. Hexadentate Ligands

    In 1963, desferrioxamine (DFO, desferal, 1) became the first clinically approved hexadentate iron chelator for treating iron overload diseases.(40) It is a microbial tris-hydroxamate siderophore isolated from Streptomyces pilosum with a low redox potential (−468 mV) and a pFe3+ value of 26.6. The thermodynamic stability of DFO is high, but its hydrophilicity and high molecular weight properties limit its absorption and oral activity.(41)
    EDTA (2a) and DTPA (2b) are aminocarboxylate ligands, which possess a high affinity for Fe3+. However, their selectivity for Fe3+ is relatively poor, leading to the toxicity when used in the clinical situation.(37)

    1.3.2. Tridentate Ligands

    Desferrithiocin (DFT, 3a) is a tridentate siderophore isolated from cultures of Streptomyces antibioticus.(42) It is orally active but has side effects of renal and neurological toxicity.(43) The analogues of DFT (deferitrin, 3b) and deferitazole (3c) have also demonstrated toxic effects in clinical trials.(44,45)
    Pyridoxal isonicotinoyl hydrazone (PIH, 4a) and salicylaldehyde isonicotinoyl hydrazone (SIH, 4b) were initially identified as iron chelators in 1979.(46) They can cause oxidative stress as both the ligands, and their Fe3+ complexes are redox active in the intracellular environment.(47)
    Deferasirox (DFX, Exjade, 5) is an oral chelator approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration in 2005 for the treatment of transfusional iron overload.(48) It is 4–5 times more capable of removing iron from liver cells than DFO.(49) The extreme hydrophobicity of DFX renders it able to penetrate membranes easily. It possesses good oral availability. However, DFX forms a highly charged 2:1 iron complex with a molecular weight over 800, rendering it difficult for the complex to efflux from most cells. DFX is also toxic to renal and neural tissues.(50,51)

    1.3.3. Bidentate Ligands

    Catechols (e.g., DMB, 6) and hydroxamates (e.g., acetohydroxamic acid, 7) are two common bidentate chelators with relatively weak iron chelation at physiological pH. The pFe3+ values are 15 and 13 respectively.(37) 8-Hydroxyquinoline (8) is a N-containing ligand, possessing a relatively high affinity for both Fe3+ and Fe2+ and thus also a high redox potential (−150 mV). By virtue of this redox potential, 8 has a tendency to redox cycle under biological conditions, resulting in toxicity.(39)
    In contrast, deferiprone (DFP, ferriprox, 9), which was approved by the FDA in 2011, is an HPO iron chelator with a high affinity and selectivity for Fe3+, low redox potential (−620 mV), and high pFe3+ value of 20.4.(38,52) It yields noncharged 3:1 iron(III) complexes, which can efflux from cells by nonfacilitated diffusion. It has the advantages of a strong ability to remove iron from cells and a high bioavailability.

    1.4. Advantages of Hydroxypyridinone-Based Iron Chelators

    At the present time, only DFX and DFP have been identified as orally active iron chelators suitable for clinical use. DFX is effective in removing excess iron from the liver and possesses acceptable tolerance. However, DFX is associated with many adverse events, such as renal toxicity, transient rash, and gastrointestinal disturbances.(53) DFP, an HPO-based iron chelator, has been used to treat systemic iron overload diseases for over two decades.(52) It is effective in removing excess iron from the heart and liver but is associated with reversible agranulocytosis in approximately 1% of patients receiving the drug.(53−55) Thus, neither compound is ideal, and the search for improved orally active iron chelators continues.
    HPOs have high iron selectivity and affinity for iron. They are O,O-“hard” ligands that can form stable bonds with high-spin Fe3+ (hard Lewis acid) by virtue of their high charge density.(35) This high charge density is also associated with a high affinity for protons. The pKa values of DFP are 3.7 and 9.8.(38,56) The high pKa value of the carbonyl function and the superior affinity of HPOs for iron(III) result from the extensive delocalization of the lone pair electrons associated with the nitrogen atom on the pyridinone ring (Figure 3).(57) Low pH sensitivity is reflected in the ability of HPOs to form stable neutral 3:1 iron(III) complexes at physiological pH, which is stable over a wide range of pH values. These neutral complexes can readily penetrate cell membranes by simple diffusion because of their relatively low molecular weight and noncharged properties. This facilitates the removal of iron from iron-overloaded cells.(36,37) HPOs possess the highest pFe3+ values among the O,O-bidentate ligands, and the affinity for Fe3+ is much higher than that of divalent metal ions, rendering HPO’s selective for Fe3+ under biological conditions.(39)
    HPOs, when coordinating iron, completely envelop the surface of iron and thus minimize the production of hydroxyl radicals at physiological pH.(37) Therefore, HPO complexes are less susceptible to oxidation.(35,58) The low redox potential of the iron complexes (DFP, −620 mV) renders it unlikely to redox cycle under biological conditions.(38,59) Bidentate HPOs do not inhibit haem-containing enzymes; however, they can interfere with non-heme-containing enzymes, such as the lipoxygenase and aromatic hydroxylase families and ribonucleotide reductase. However, HPOs causing minimal enzyme inhibition can be designed by modification of the ring substituents.(35) HPOs can be readily modified to introduce other active groups, thereby developing new pharmacological properties.(6,58−65) By virtue of their excellent iron chelation, and nontoxic properties of their iron complexes, they are among the most promising iron chelators for clinical use.

    2. Pharmacological Applications of Hydroxypyridinone Derivatives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In this section, the broad-ranging pharmacological applications of HPO derivatives are presented. It is hoped that the content and organization of this section will prove to be useful to medicinal chemists embarking on the exploitation of HPOs.

    2.1. Hydroxypyridinones for the Treatment of Systemic Iron Overload

    Systemic iron overload diseases mainly include hereditary hemochromatosis (HH) and secondary hemochromatosis.(2,66) HH is caused by genetic defects such as HAMP, TFR, and other mutations, and secondary hemochromatosis is caused by exogenous iron supplementation therapy or long-term repeated blood transfusions such as is required in the treatment of thalassemia, sickle cell disease, sideroblastic anemia, and myelodysplastic syndromes.(67,68) In these patients, excess iron cannot be removed from the body and is deposited in the form of hemosiderin and ferritin in the spleen, liver, endocrine organs, and myocardium, which in the long term lead to organ degeneration, diffuse fibrosis, and metabolic and functional disorders, such as liver failure, cardiac failure, and retinal degeneration.(69)

    2.1.1. DFP and CP94

    DFP is the only bidentate oral alternative to DFO and has been in clinical use since the late 1980s. It is more efficient at removing cardiac iron than DFO.(70) Although DFP has the advantages of powerful iron chelation and the noncharged nature of the iron complex, its bioavailability is limited by the rapid phase II metabolism involving the glucuronidation of the 3-hydroxyl function of DFP. The 3-hydroxyl group is essential for chelation and iron clearance, and in some patients more than 85% of DFP is converted to the nonchelating 3-O-glucuronide, resulting in lower efficacy.(71)
    The DFP analogue CP94 (10) was also investigated, as it was found to have a higher iron removal capacity than DFP in several rodent and primate models. This is due to a different phase I metabolic pathway to that of DFP, which leads to the formation of the 2-(1′-hydroxyethyl) metabolite lacking glucuronide conjugates.(72) However, in humans, the 3-O-glucuronide conjugation is the major metabolite so much so that CP94 (10) was ineffective at mobilizing iron in humans.(73)

    2.1.2. N-Substituted HPOs

    The influence of the nature of the N-substituted 2-alkyl-3-hydroxy-4(1H)-pyridinones has been systematically investigated for its influence on biological properties.(74)N-Substituents have little effect on iron affinity but have major effects on the ability to remove iron and on toxic side effects. Compounds with a distribution coefficient between 0.5 and 2.0 were found to be more effective than those with a coefficient less than 0.2. Compound 11 was found to be the most potent among simple derivatives at removing iron from iron-overloaded mice.
    Subsequently, the same workers evaluated and compared N-(carboxyalkyl)- and N-(hydroxyalkyl)-2-alkyl-3-hydroxypyridin-4-ones. CP102 (12a), a N-hydroxyethyl compound, was found to be the most efficient at facilitating the excretion of iron in bile, while not being metabolized.(75) However, CP102 proved to be too hydrophilic and was associated with poor hepatic extraction.(76)
    Recently, it has been discovered that the introduction of diverse chiral amino alcohols at the N-1 position of the 3-hydroxypyridin-4-ones can serve as an alternate sacrificial site for glucuronidation, reducing the metabolic problems associated with the 3-hydroxyl function. The LogP values, pharmacokinetic properties, and in vivo efficacy can be modulated by both the variation of substituents on amino alcohol side chains and the chiral configuration.(77) Most compounds in this series possess higher LogP values, cell membrane penetration rate, and oral efficiency than DFP. CN128 (13) was found to possess optimal properties as it possesses lower glucuronidation and oxidation rates, is more lipophilic (LogP = 0.58), possesses superior iron scavenging ability to that of DFP, possesses a good oral pharmacokinetic profile, and is well tolerated. CN128 is currently in clinical trials for the treatment of β-thalassemia.(77)

    2.1.3. Lipophilic HPOs and Prodrugs

    Zanninelli demonstrated that the compounds CP102 (12a), CP41 (14a), together with their respective prodrugs CP117 (12b) and CP165 (14b) can promote the biliary excretion of iron originating as plasma 55Fe-NTBI and increase the cumulative recovery of 55Fe in iron-overloaded rats by 30–70 fold.(78) Rai also described a range of hydrophobic ester prodrugs of 1-hydroxyalkyl HPOs. These hydrophobic prodrugs are absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and cleaved in the hepatocyte yielding 1-hydroxyalkyl HPOs (Figure 4). The pivaloyl ester 12b was found to be more stable and to cause superior iron excretion than the corresponding benzoyl ester prodrugs.(79) Indeed, a wide range of ester prodrugs were investigated and found to be more efficient than both 12a and 14a.(76) Although some of these prodrugs were found to be superior at iron removal when compared to DFP, none generated a sufficiently large enhancement to initiate toxicity studies.
    The intestinal transport and oral bioavailability of the iron chelator maltosine (15) are increased by conversion to peptide prodrugs. The transepithelial flux of the dipeptide prodrug derivatives 16a and 16b were 14-fold and 8-fold higher than that of maltosine, respectively. These HPOs are transported by human peptide transporter 1 (hPEPT1) into intestinal cells and then hydrolyzed to free maltosine. Compounds 16 have been suggested to possess potential for the treatment of iron storage diseases.(80)
    CP411 (17, LogP = 0.96) and CM1 (18, LogP = 0.53, pFe3+ = 20.3) readily enter the hepatocyte due to their suitable lipophilicity values and were both found to be 2.5 times more effective than DFP (LogP = 0.17) at mobilizing iron in vivo.(63,81) However, the phase II metabolism of CM1 is relatively high, and this led to investigation of pegylated HPOs with the possibility of a reduction in their rate of metabolism. For the most promising compound 19, glucuronidation was reduced to 20% of that of DFP. However, the LogP value of 19 (LogP = −2.01) is low and so reduces the rate of penetration of membranes by nonfacilitated diffusion. Further optimization is required.(82)

    2.1.4. HPOs with a High pFe3+ Value

    In order to reduce toxicity and improve chelating efficiency, so that chelators can remove iron effectively at lower concentrations, a series of 1-, 2-, and 6-substituted HPOs possessing higher pFe3+ values than that of DFP have been synthesized (Table 1).
    Table 1. pFe Values and Iron Mobilization Efficacy of Compounds
    compoundpFe3+iron mobilization efficacy (%) dose at 450 μmol/kg–1
    DFP20.413.4 ± 5.2
    20a21.060.4 ± 15.6
    20b21.454.5 ± 9.9
    21a21.758.7 ± 7.8
    21b22.850.1 ± 9.6
    2222.0NAa
    a

    NA means not available

    The introduction of a 1′-hydroxyalkyl group at the C-2 position of the HPO ring (20) significantly reduces the pKa values and consequently increases the pFe3+ values. These compounds do not undergo rapid glucuronidation and were found to greatly facilitate iron excretion (Table 1).(73) A similar strategy involved the introduction of an amido function at the 2-position. Compounds CP502 (21a, pFe3+ = 21.7) and CP511 (21b, pFe3+ = 22.8) were found to be the most effective in this series, providing 59% and 50% iron excretion in the iron-loaded rat, respectively, compared with 13.4% for that of DFP (pFe3+ = 20.4).(83,84) The cause of the low pKa values and resulting high pFe3+ values are due to the combined effect of intramolecular hydrogen bonding between the 2-substituents with the adjacent 3-hydroxyl group and the negative inductive effect of the 2-substituents from the HPO ring. The X-ray diffraction structures of CP511 demonstrate its ionization pathway and the critically strong intramolecular hydrogen bond (Figure 5).(84)
    Recently, Lachowicz presented a study on the coordination ability of compound 22 toward Fe3+ by combining computational, chemical, and biological approaches.(85)22 possesses a high pFe3+ value (22.0) because its tautomeric isomer is analogous to catechol and the lower protonation constant of the 3-OH group (Figure 6). The biodistribution studies with mice demonstrated that 22 was equally effective to DFP, rendering the molecule as a possible candidate for the treatment of iron overload.

    2.1.5. Macromolecular HPOs

    In principle, administering iron chelators with a high molecular weight to reduce the efficiency of iron absorption from the intestine is an alternative method of relieving iron overload. Dendrimers and polymers cannot be readily absorbed by the gastrointestinal tract and will irreversibly form nontoxic, kinetically inert iron complexes that are not absorbed and so are excreted in the feces. For this purpose, a range of HPO-based dendrimers (e.g., 23–24) and polymers (e.g., 25) were synthesized.(86,87) Dendritic and polymeric chelators bind iron with high affinity (pFe3+ ≈ 28.5) and so have a real potential for reducing Fe3+ absorption from the intestine.(86−89)

    2.1.6. Combination Therapy

    Combination therapy is an effective method to treat iron overload diseases and is widely adopted. Some patients, particularly those with severe iron overload, fail to respond adequately to monotherapy. Combination therapy generates a great difference in the pharmacokinetics of iron removal as demonstrated by the synergism of the two chelators DFP and DFO. These two chelators possess different tissue distributions and accessed different iron pools. The small orally active chelator DFP has a more extensive distribution than DFO and gains access to a wide range of cells. The hexadentate DFO functions as a competitive coligand, scavenges iron from the weaker DFP/iron complex, and facilitates excretion (Figure 7).(59) The combination of DFP and DFO improves iron excretion, plasma NTBI removal, and the reduction of liver iron, serum ferritin, and cardiac iron. It also improves tolerability, compliance, and survival, rendering adverse effects manageable through dose adjustment.(90,91) Combination therapy enhances efficacy and reduces side effects.
    In general, the prospect of 1-, 2-, or 6-substituted HPOs with high pFe3+ values, HPO-based prodrugs, HPO-based dendrimers, and combination therapy using HPOs with other iron chelators is likely to improve iron chelation therapy of patients suffering from systemic iron overload in future years.

    2.2. Hydroxypyridinones as Neuroprotection Agents

    NDDs are a class of progressive and fatal complex diseases, such as Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and Parkinson’s disease (PD). The pathogenesis of these diseases is complicated, and there is no clear etiology. The main characteristics of these diseases are the loss of neurons and protein deposition in specific regions of the brain.(92) Currently, there is a lack of effective therapies. Among the various pathogeneses in NDDs, iron imbalance and oxidative stress have been associated with progressive neurodegeneration and abnormal protein aggregation.(27) Mitochondria iron overload has been demonstrated to be a key feature of Friedreich’s ataxia (FRDA).(93) Interference with iron homeostasis and transport mechanisms will lead to the accumulation of Fe3+, which will eventually lead to the formation of ROS, oxidative stress, mitochondrial damage, and cell death through free radical reactions.(94) Studies have shown that FPN is decreased in damaged neurons, and heme deposition occurs in regions with blood vessel lesions.(11) A high concentration of iron and an increase in iron accumulation in pathologic cells lead to increased deposition of Aβ and an overphosphorylation of the normal τ-protein.(27)
    In principle, iron chelators are potential therapeutic agents for NDDs and have been demonstrated to be effective against NDDs in a series of animal models.(32)

    2.2.1. N-Alkyl HPOs

    Many of the properties of HPOs render them capable of crossing the blood–brain barrier (BBB) and inhibiting prooxidant insults.(95) Indeed, DFP, CP94, and CP24 (26b) have been demonstrated to remove excess iron from the brain in the ferrocene-loaded rats.(96) The LogP values of N-alkyl HPOs show a direct relationship with N-alkyl chain length. However, there is a dramatic decrease in BBB permeability when a hydroxyl function is introduced on the N-alkyl group as in 26e–g.(97) However, there are practical limits to increasing the BBB permeability by increasing the LogP value because with an increase in lipophilicity there is an increase of liver first pass absorption, thereby, reducing the overall bioavailability. DFP has been involved in many clinical trials for PD and AD.(98−100) Kwiatkowski reported that after one year’s administration of DFP in PD patients, at 30 mg/kg/day, there was an improvement in the Unified Parkinson’s Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) score and a decrease in iron accumulation in the bilateral dentate nuclei, as well as the substantia nigra (SN).(98) Subsequently, Devos and Bastida also identified the beneficial effects of DFP and reported it to selectively remove iron from different brain regions.(99,100) Currently, a phase 2, randomized, placebo-controlled, multicenter study to investigate the safety and efficacy of DFP is in progress to ascertain whether DFP (15 mg/kg BID orally) slows cognitive decline in Alzheimer’s patients.(101)
    A range of fluorinated HPOs have been found to enhance BBB penetration while not increasing the liver first pass extraction.(52,102) However, there was no clear correlation between BBB permeability and LogP values. Three compounds, namely, 27c, 27d, and 27g were found to be superior to DFP, the most effective molecule being CP241 (27c).

    2.2.2. 2-Amido HPOs

    A small library of highly selective 2-amido-3-hydroxypyridin-4-one iron chelators (28) was designed for the removal of iron under neurodegenerative conditions.(103) They possessed high pFe3+ values (up to 21.5), and their LogD values (0.90–1.52) fell within the lipophilic range for efficient BBB permeability. This series of compounds was designed to provide minimal inhibition of the iron-containing enzymes, lipoxygenase, and tyrosine hydroxylase. Compounds 28c and 28f were found to be particularly weak inhibitors of both lipoxygenase and tyrosine hydroxylase at 10 μM, while 28g, 28h, and 28j were lipophilic derivatives that showed considerable inhibition on these enzymes at the same concentration. 28c and 28f were found to reverse FeNTA-induced primary cortical neuron death in a concentration-dependent manner, and this study clearly proved that Aβ (3 or 10 μM)-induced neuronal cell death was reversed when treated with low concentrations of iron chelators, indicating the negative role of iron in the Aβ neurotoxic effects. However, in further in vivo studies neither 28c or 28f was found to efficiently penetrate the BBB.

    2.2.3. 1-Hydroxypyridin-2-ones

    Novel 1-hydroxypyridin-2-one iron chelators (29–32) have also been compared with DFP for their neuroprotective properties in a PD culture model induced by the catecholaminergic neurotoxin 6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA) to lesion cellular dopaminergic pathways.(104)30 and 31 demonstrated a similar defense against 6-OHDA neurotoxicity and iron insults to those of DFP, and provided a similar neuroprotective effect from PD-related neurotoxins.(104) In contrast, 29 and 32 had no significant protective effect, indicating that the relative locations of the carboxylic acid and hydroxymethyl has profound effects on neuroprotection. Compound 30 was found to provide the greatest protection against 6-OHDA. The same 6-OHDA cell viability assay of the nonmetal binding analogues (e.g., 32) demonstrated that the hydroxamic acid iron-binding functionality of 30 was indeed essential for neuroprotection against 6-OHDA.

    2.2.4. HPO-Glucosides

    Because of the heavy glucose dependence of the brain, the BBB is endowed with a high concentration of the hexose transporters. In principle, it should be possible to enhance the BBB permeability of chelators by coupling the chelators to hexoses.
    Feralex-G (33) has been reported to have potential for the therapy of various neurodegenerative diseases, but has not been further developed.(105) Orvig’s group presented a series of modified and functionalized bidentate HPO proligands by using glucose as a mask and directing substituent to solve the potential problem of premature binding of metals (34).(106−108) Once the glucoside is hydrolyzed, these compounds (34a–d) exhibit iron-chelating and antioxidant properties.(106) In principle, they could significantly reduce the amount of aggregated Aβ. The inclusion of a methylene group (34b vs 34c) had little effect on the in vitro antioxidant capacity, toxicity, and ability to dissolve Aβ aggregates.(107) None of these derivatives have been tested under in vivo conditions. N-Substituted HPO glycosylation prodrugs (34f–s), which partly incorporate a framework derived from thioflavin-T (ThT), were also evaluated.(108) The antioxidant capacities of all the nonglycosylated proligands (HL1–HL7) were better than that of the positive control α-tocopherol. Furthermore, a study of brain uptake with the radiolabeled glycoconjugate pyridinone 125I-Gipp/125I-GL7 using an in situ rat brain perfusion technique indicated adequate cerebral uptake of this prodrug, establishing the initial effectiveness of brain permeable pyridinones as AD therapeutics. However, the suggestion that the glycosylation of HPOs is a feasible method of enhancing the brain uptake of such compounds has been disputed.(109) By directly comparing the brain absorption of DFP with its glycosylated analogue 34a in mice using in situ cerebral perfusion. No brain uptake of 34a was observed, which is likely to be due to the high hydrophilicity of this molecule. The complete inability of the glycosylated analogue (34a) to cross the BBB indicates that BBB hexose transporters are unlikely to be involved in the permeation of this type of prodrug. Thus, at present, glycosylation of bidentate HPOs has not been clearly demonstrated to facilitate penetration of the BBB.

    2.2.5. HPO-Carbamates

    Prodrugs resulting from functionalizing hydroxyl groups in the form of carbamates can in principle improve the pharmacokinetics by reducing metabolism and excretion. To obtain the molecules with acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitory activity, a carbamate group was introduced to mimic rivastigmine (35). After brain uptake, the carbamate is partially hydrolyzed by enzymes. Nerve cell line activity tests demonstrated that Cppp (36a) was not toxic at high concentrations (450–650 μM), and the AChE inhibitory activity was enhanced with an IC50 value of 48.8 μM compared to Hppp (36b, 210 μM).(110)
    This multifunctional HPO scaffold was further explored by means of computational studies. Two new features were investigated: one the carbamate was attached to the HPO ring by a benzyl ether linker, and the second was that the iron-binding site remained intact, the carbamate being relocated to the N-substituent of the HPO.(111) After the preliminary screen of the initial database, 15 compounds were selected for molecular docking studies on AChE protein. Cbppp (37) had the best docking score of −5.59 kcal/mol, followed by Cchpp (38) and Chpp (39). All compounds had similar reversible AChE inhibitory activity, with IC50 values in the range of 200–350 μM. The structure–activity relationship (SAR) investigation showed that the carbamate group directly attached to the hydroxyl group (36a) on the pyridinone ring was more efficient than when placed at other positions.

    2.2.6. HPO-Phenol/propargyl Hybrids

    In principle, the combination of iron chelators and free radical scavengers can protect living tissues from oxidative stress to a greater degree than that of chelators alone. A small library of such compounds was demonstrated to be potent inhibitors of lipid peroxidation.(112) All compounds (40a–f) showed enhanced inhibitory effects on lipid peroxidation when compared to DFP and the antioxidants butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT), trolox, and di-tert-butyl peroxide (DTBP). 40a and 40b were the most effective lipid peroxidation inhibitors, providing the optimal protection against indoleacetic acid (IAA)-induced cytotoxicity. 40b showed significantly enhanced neuroprotection by inhibiting oxidative stress, which was superior to that provided by DTBP or DFP.
    Other 1-phenol-HPO derivatives (e.g., 41) were designed as quadruply functional agents for AD therapy. Such compounds not only possessed metal ion chelation, Aβ aggregation inhibition, and radical scavenging capacity, but also are specific H3 receptor antagonists. H3 receptor antagonists can increase cognition-related neurotransmitters in the brain.(113)In vivo studies were performed through intraperitoneal administration of 41 (5 mg/kg) in male Sprague–Dawley rats. The results showed that 41 demonstrated acceptable exposure (636 ± 64 ng·h/mL), suitable half-life (1.6 ± 0.1 h), high volumes of distribution (18.7 ± 0.9 L/kg) in plasma, a mean Cmax of 207 ng/mL in the brain within half an hour, and a brain/plasma exposure ratio of 0.69, which indicates that 41 had appropriate pharmacokinetics values and good BBB penetration.
    Conjugation of propargylamine and HPOs have also been investigated for their potential role in monoamine oxidase-B (MAO-B) inhibition.(114) The propargyl function is a key pharmacophore in many MAO-B inhibitors such as rasagiline and selegiline. Three such compounds (42–44) exhibited improved cell viability in cells treated with MPP+ or Aβ1–42. Compounds 42, 43, and 44 were found to more effective than DFP in MPP+-induced cell death by inhibiting caspase. They also showed neuroprotective and antiapoptotic effects, 42 being the most efficient product. The addition of other active groups to the N of propargyl or to the HPO ring may result in multitarget inhibition besides iron chelation and MAO-B inhibition. To date, these compounds have not been progressed any further.

    2.2.7. HPO-Benzothiazole Hybrids

    Benzothiazole (BTA) is known for its strong affinity for amyloid fibrils and consequently has been used in the design of Aβ imaging probes. A virtual screen against AChE was implemented to optimize appropriate spacers between HPO and BTA.(115) All these compounds had a higher AChE enzyme affinity compared with HPO alone. Series 45 exerted relatively good BBB permeability and AChE inhibition similar to prodrugs, while series 46 had high iron chelation (pFe3+ = 19.2–19.4). Compounds 45c and 46d displayed the most potent resistance to Aβ, AChE inhibition, and antioxidant capacity.
    The effects of the benzothiazole and benzoxazole functionalities on metal chelation, antioxidant activity, and cytotoxicity have been systematically investigated by Telpoukhovskaia and co-workers (47–51). Compound 49, with a phenyl group directly bound to the pyridone, exhibited a higher antioxidant activity than 47 and 48.(116) They also reported two compounds (50 and 51) designing for fluorescence studies to determine interaction with Aβ as well as cell permeability. The difference of one atom (sulfur or oxygen) showed that compared with 50, the interaction between 51 and the protein resulted in enhanced fluorescence, indicating that the benzothiazole-derivative 51 exhibited greater binding affinity to Aβ and higher permeability than its analogous benzoxazole-derivative 50.(117)
    Resveratrol (52) is a natural distyrene derivative with multiple activities including free radical scavenging activity and high anti-Aβ aggregation inhibition. Compounds (53) were obtained by connecting benzothiazole with HPO groups through a vinyl moiety. These compounds have activities against metal ions, Aβ aggregation, and oxidative stress, showing a good triple effect.(118) Two optimal compounds, 53a and 53b, exhibited excellent anti-Aβ aggregation activity, high ABTS (2,2′-azino-bis(3-ethylbenzthiazoline-6-sulfonic acid)) radical scavenger activity, strong metal chelation properties, and depolymerization activity against previously formed fibers. In addition, no cytotoxicity was found in human glioma U251 cells at concentrations less than 50 μM.
    SAR revealed that the modification of benzothiazole ring significantly affected the activity. The compounds containing benzoxazole and benzothiazole displayed better antioxidant activity than N-Me benzoimidazole derivatives. The introduction of methoxy or hydroxy moiety into the C-6 position or a hydroxy moiety into the C-2 position of benzothiazole resulted in a remarkable enhancement of activity, while the bromo and methoxy moieties were not favorable for activity. Furthermore, the substituents at the C-2 position of pyranone impacted the activity slightly; however, the methyl group in the C-1 position decreased the antioxidant capacities obviously, indicating the detrimental steric effect on antioxidant activity.(118) In general, C-2 and C-6 hydroxyl substituted benzothiazole ring and unsubstituted pyranone were superior.

    2.2.8. HPO-Resveratrol/Tacrine/Donepezil Hybrids

    Because of the efficient Aβ aggregation inhibitory and radical scavenging activities of resveratrol (52), a series of DFP-resveratrol hybrids (54) were investigated. These compounds were found to possess iron chelation, antioxidant, and anti-Aβ aggregation activities.(119) They showed antioxidant activity superior to that of Trolox, and an inhibitory effect on Aβ1–42 aggregation superior to that of resveratrol and curcumin. The SAR analysis of a large of analogues demonstrated that the introduction of hydroxyl, alkoxy, and other electron-donating groups to positions 2 and 4 of the benzene ring was crucial to the aggregation inhibition of Aβ1–42. Molecular docking analysis with Aβ1–42 monomer model of compounds 54a and 54b indicated that they can effectively interact with the C-terminus of Aβ1–42 through hydrogen bonding. Compounds 54a and 54b were identified as the most promising multitarget chelators with triple functions, with micromolar IC50 values against Aβ1–42 aggregation.
    Tacrine (55) and donepezil (57) are AChE inhibitors approved by the FDA for the treatment of AD. In order to design multitarget-directed ligands (MTDLs) with AChE inhibitory activities, a variety of functional groups have been hybridized with 55 and 57, including HPOs. Molecular docking showed that 2–3 methylene chains coupled to tacrine and HPO resulted in a good double-binding interaction between the compound and the active sites (CAS and PAS).(120) The AChE inhibitory activities of those compounds with chloro-substitution and hydroxyl-containing linkers were close to that of tacrine, and the IC50 values were within the range of 0.64–1.01 μM. Free radical scavenging activity was moderate (μM range) and higher than that of tacrine alone. Compounds 56a and 56b showed the most potent inhibitory effect on AChE with the IC50 values of 0.96 μM and 0.86 μM displaying the most potential Aβ1–42 self-aggregation inhibition in the range of 85–95%.
    Similarly, O-benzyl-HPO and benzofuran groups of compound 58 could simulate donepezil benzyl piperidine and dimethoxyindone, respectively, while 2-methylene-linked hybrid compounds could double bind with the binding sites of each of the active sites (CAS and PAS).(121) Therefore, the effects of n, R1, and R2 on the activity were investigated. O-Benzyl-HPO hybrid (58a) containing a 2-methylene linker was the most similar to donepezil, although its activity was still lower than donepezil. However, the free-HPO hybrid (58b) presented a higher activity for Aβ aggregation inhibition and higher metal chelating capacity and radical scavenging activity. These compounds also showed a moderate positive neuroprotective effects in neuronal cells, which could serve as a basis for further development of potential multifunctional drug or pro-drug candidates for AD.

    2.2.9. HPO-Coumarin Hybrids

    A series of HPO-coumarin hybrids have been designed, synthesized, and evaluated as multitargeting agents against AD.
    Initially, click chemistry was applied to connect the N-1 position of HPOs with the C-3, C-4, and C-7 positions of coumarins.(122) All hybrids displayed excellent iron-chelating activity and the MAO-B inhibitory activity. Most of the 3- or 7-substituted coumarin derivatives were significantly better than those of the 4-substituted compounds. Compounds 59a and 59b exhibited the most potent MAO-B inhibitory activity with IC50 values of 0.68 and 0.86 μM, respectively.
    Replacing the heterocyclic link with a simple alkyl chain generated compounds with a more potent MAO-B inhibitory activity, with IC50 values ranging from submicromolar to low nanomolar concentrations.(123) Compound 60a exhibited the most potent activity against MAO-B with an IC50 value of 14.7 nM. This compound also showed a good protective effect on U251 cells and significantly ameliorated the cognitive dysfunction of scopolamine-induced AD mice.
    Simultaneously, replacing the heterocyclic link with an amide chain also generated compounds with a more potent MAO-B inhibitory activity than 59, with IC50 values around 100 nM.(124) The MAO-B inhibitory activity of the C-7 substituted coumarin derivatives was significantly better than those of the C-6/8 substituted compounds. Compound 61a was the most potent MAO-B inhibitor with an IC50 value of 87.9 nM, which was more efficient than 60b. Moreover, compound 61a exerted favorable antioxidant activity, significantly reversed the Aβ1–42 induced PC12 cell damage, and also remarkably ameliorated the cognitive dysfunction in a scopolamine-induced mice AD model.
    Molecular docking with MAO-B elucidated the probable ligand–receptor interaction, the HPO moiety was toward the FAD cofactor, and it had important interactions with residues around it, indicating that the HPO moiety not only functions as a chelating agent but also provides a key fragment in binding with MAO-B. Compounds 60a and 61a are currently the optimal compounds and deserve further structural optimization. It may be possible to simplify the coumarin structure in order to obtain more flexible molecules that bind more tightly to the enzyme cavity.

    2.2.10. Summary

    To date, there have only been minor improvements over DFP by simple structural modification, such as rendering the alkyl substituents more lipophilic or introducing fluorine atoms. Although the conjugation with glucose residues is an attractive idea, there is currently no strong evidence for enhanced BBB permeability. The design of hybrids of HPOs and other pharmacophore groups looks more promising. Combinations with propargyl and tacrine appear to have potential for future development.

    2.3. Hydroxypyridinones as Antibacterial Agents

    Iron is necessary for the growth of almost all microorganisms. The “nutritional immunity” strategy can be used for antibacterial therapy by extracting essential metal ions, especially iron from the bacterial environment.(125) However, bacteria and fungi can produce siderophores, which are strong iron chelators that scavenge iron from the environment.(126) High iron affinity iron chelators can compete with siderophores for iron and thereby inhibit microorganism growth and so reduce the risk of infection.

    2.3.1. N-Alkyl Bidentate HPOs

    HPOs, as strong iron-chelating agents, inhibit the growth of several bacteria and fungi. The antibacterial effects of HPOs possessing different substituents at positions 2, 3, 5, and 6 on the pyridinone ring have been investigated.(127,128) Quantitative structure–activity relationships (QSAR) were studied using the microplate Alamar Blue assay method and counter propagation artificial neural networks (CP-ANN) method. Compounds 62–65 were reported to possess antimicrobial activity against Candida albicans and Staphylococcus aureus.(128) Faidallah characterized a further 58 HPO derivatives, 26 of which exhibited inhibitory effects on the growth of Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, 66 being the most potent antibacterial agent.(129)

    2.3.2. Hexadentate HPOs

    The antimicrobial activity of a range of hexadentate HPO chelators has been evaluated by Zhou and co-workers.(130−136) There are two main structural types of these hexadentate chelators: one conjugating an alkyl triamine (CP251, 67) or aromatic triamine (CP252, 68) with three bidentate units, and the other using a tripodal structure with three carboxyl groups to anchor the bidentate units (71–73).
    Compounds 67 and 68 were compared with DTPA (2b) and was found to possess the most potent inhibitory effect on both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, followed by DTPA and then 68. Significantly 67 possesses a higher affinity for Fe3+ (LogK = 30.7, pFe3+ = 30.5) than DTPA (LogK = 28.6) and is more water-soluble than 68.(130) Both 69a and 69b demonstrated similar antibacterial activity to 67.(131) In order to investigate the effect of hydrophobicity on the antibacterial activity of hexadentate HPOs, a series with different substituents on nitrogen were synthesized (70a–i). Overall, 70c with a cLogP value of −3.6 showed optimal bacterial growth inhibitory activity.(132)
    Compound 71b exhibited inhibitory activity against Providencia stuartii and Staphylococcus aureus in vitro, with minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) values of 320 and 240 μg/mL, respectively.(133) Compound 71b was found to be more effective when used in combination with chloramphenicol.(133) More hydrophilic analogues 72a and 72e showed optimal bacterial growth inhibitory effects against S. aureus, Bacillus subtilis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and E. coli, with MIC values of 8, 8, 16, and 8 μg/mL, respectively.(134)72b–d, 72f–h, and 72i showed moderate inhibitory effects against P. aeruginosa with MIC values of 32, 32, and 128 μg/mL, respectively. Compounds 72g and 72i possessed the poor inhibitory effects against these four strains. This indicates that the presence of a charged amino group may influence the penetration of compounds into the surface of bacteria and thereby a detrimental influence on the antibacterial effect. For noncharged compounds (72a–f), hydrophobic compounds showed lower inhibitory activity.
    The overuse and misuse of antibiotics has led to the emergence of the multidrug-resistant bacteria, especially methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA), which has been associated with severe wound infections. A series of hexadentate HPOs have been investigated for their antimicrobial activity against MRSA, and 73 showed inhibitory activity against both the Gram-positive bacteria MRSA and the Gram-negative bacteria P. aeruginosa.(136) SAR indicated that lipophilic chelators can enhance the inhibition of MRSA. The two most hydrophobic compounds 73j and 73k possessed the highest inhibitory activity against MRSA. However, 73j, 73k, and the highly hydrophilic 73f were found to possess low MIC values against P. aeruginosa.

    2.3.3. HPO–Rosamine Conjugates

    The antimycobacterial properties of a series of fluorescent rosamine HPO hexadentate iron chelators were evaluated by Rangel and co-workers.(137,138) Bidentate HPOs were found to lack an inhibitory effect on the growth of Mycobacterium avium in mouse macrophages. Similarly, the hexadentate chelators 67 and 68 had no inhibitory effect on the intra-macrophagic growth of M. avium. In contrast, hexadentate HPOs connected to a fluorescent entity were found to inhibit the intramacrophagic growth of M. avium.(137,138) CP777 (74b) demonstrated the strongest inhibitory activity of this tripodal series 74. CP777 (74b) successfully competes with carboxy-mycobactin and mycobactin for iron, providing a mechanism for the observed antibacterial action. These molecules thus offer an effective antibacterial strategy that may be used to combat infections, including tuberculosis.
    Rangel and co-workers also investigated the activity of the rhodamine-labeled HPO chelators (75–81) against Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria.(139) Among these chelators, the hexadentate chelators (75–77) were found to possess a stronger antibacterial activity than that of the bidentate chelators (78–80). Both 75 and 77 could inhibit the growth of Gram-positive bacteria S. aureus ATCC 25923 and S. epidermis ATCC 12228 with an MIC value of 0.016 mM. Compound 75 possessed higher bacterial inhibition than compounds 76 and 77, with an MIC of 0.063 mM against Gram-negative bacteria E. coli ATCC 25922. The superior antibacterial effect of compounds 75 could be attributed to the presence of thiourea linkage and N-ethyl substituents on the xanthene ring, which increased their lipophilicity, thereby enhancing their ability to penetrate the biological membranes. However, surprisingly, bidentate chelator 81 exhibited the most potent inhibition among all the rhodamine-labeled HPO chelators (75–81) against Gram-positive strains from different genera and species with MIC values of 0.011–0.022 mM, such as the clinically relevant species S. aureus, S. epidermidis, E. faecium, and E. faecalis.(140) This enhanced activity may be due to the absence of one carboxyl group on the position 2′ of phenyl ring in compound 81, thus possessing a positive charge at neutral pH, which may increase the antibacterial effect by favoring the occurrence of electrostatic interactions with the surface of the bacterial membrane.

    2.3.4. Macromolecular HPOs

    Macromolecular iron chelators, such as dendrimers and polymers, have considerable potential in the medical area due to their many advantages over the traditional small-molecule drugs. They can effectively bind iron irreversibly to form nontoxic, kinetically inert complexes that are not absorbed by the mammalian gastrointestinal tract.(141) The first macromolecular HPO chelators were prepared by immobilizing HPO onto sepharose gels. Initially, a series of monomers with 3-hydroxy-2-methyl-4(lH)-pyridinone (HMP) groups were synthesized (82–84).(142) These compounds (82–84) were water-soluble and found to inhibit the growth of Escherichia coli and Listeria inocula bacteria. However, it is difficult to separate water-soluble iron chelators from the treated effluents; iron was chelated but not removed from the system, resulting in toxicity. Therefore, water-insoluble iron-chelating resins were investigated (AHMP-DMAA, 85).(143) Compound 85 exhibited similar antibacterial activity compared to that of 82–84 against E. coli and L. inocula.
    A series of HPO hexadentate-functionalized iron-chelating copolymers 87 were synthesized by copolymerization of compound 86 with 2-hydroxyethyl acrylate (HEA) at different molar ratios.(135) It was found that monomer 86 and polymer 87 possessed similar pFe3+ values, 29.7 and 29.8, respectively. Both exhibited appreciable inhibitory activity with a similar MIC value (41–82 μM) against both Gram-positive (S. aureus and B. subtilis) and Gram-negative bacteria (E. coli, Salmonella spp. and P. aeruginosa), indicating that both 86 and 87 inhibit bacterial growth by removing iron from the bacterial environment. Such compounds have the potential for the treatment wound infections. There are two potential advantages of the polymer 87 when applied in wound healing. First, it may be covalently coupled to wound dressing materials; second, it is less likely to gain access to the systemic circulation when administered topically. It has also been reported that a series of macromolecular iron chelators prepared via RAFT-polymerization can inhibit the growth of MRSA.(144)
    The antimicrobial activity of some HPO hexadentate-based dendritic chelators was evaluated by Zhou and co-workers. Among the three tested dendritic chelators, 24 showed the best antibacterial activity against two Gram-negative bacteria (E. coli and P. aeruginosa), while its antibacterial activity against Gram-positive bacteria (S. aureus and B. subtilis) was not as good as that of DFP.(145) This is probably because compound 24 inhibits the growth of bacteria by scavenging iron around the surface of bacteria, whereas the inhibitory effect of DFP can be attributed its small molecular weight, which renders it accessible to the bacterial cytosol. When 24 was used in combination with norfloxacin, a synergistic inhibitory effect against both S. aureus and E. coli was observed. The higher the concentration of chelator 24, the stronger the synergism exhibited, possibly suggesting that the microorganisms are more sensitive to norfloxacin under the conditions of iron deprivation.
    More recently, Zhou’s group synthesized a range of novel hexadentate HPO-terminated dendrimers (88) using a convergent strategy.(146) These chelators exhibited marked inhibition against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. Compounds 88a and 88b displayed the highest bacterial inhibition rates against P. aeruginosa/S. aureus (88a: 90.4%, 88b: 90.0%) and E. coli/B. subtilis (88a: 99.7%, 88b: 95.0%). These dendritic chelators (or their combination with antibiotics) may have clinical potential, especially in the treatment of external infections, such as in the gastrointestinal tract, wounds, and ulcers.(89)
    Holbein reported the synthesis of a novel HPO-based polymeric chelator, DIBI (89b), by the copolymerization of an HPO methacrylamide monomer (89a) and N-vinylpyrrolidone. A series of DIBI related copolymers (MW of 2–9 kDa) were prepared. MIC assays indicated that DIBI was effective in inhibiting the Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacterial reference strains S. aureus, A. baumannii, and C. albicans. Compared with the small molecular iron chelators DFO and DFP, DIBI inhibited the initial bacterial growth by 100–1000-fold.(147) The sensitivity study indicated that DIBI possessed a potent inhibitory effect on all the 18 isolates of S. aureus from human, bovine, and canine infections, being almost 100-fold greater than those of DFP. Antibiotic-resistant and antibiotic-sensitive isolates, including hospital-acquired and community-acquired MRSA, showed susceptibility similar to DIBI.(148)

    2.3.5. HPOs with β-Lactams

    A series of 14 cephalosporins with an oxadiazolyl HPO moiety at C-7 have been investigated for in vitro and in vivo antibacterial activity.(149) The most selected cephalosporins against P. aeruginosa were found to be superior to that of cefotaxime (CTX) in vitro. Among them, compounds containing a pyridinium thiomethyl group (90) at the C-3 position were found to possess a higher efficacy against both S. aureus and P. aeruginosa. Compound 90b showed the best efficacy and was more than 10-fold potent compared with CTX and ceftazidime (CAZ) in vivo. In particular, for the protective effect against S. aureus, it showed that 90b (ED50: 0.96 mg/kg) had superior protective effects compared to that of cefpirome (ED50: 1.5 mg/kg).
    To identify new agents for the treatment of multidrug-resistant P. aeruginosa, and to solve the known problems of the physical properties and stability of monocyclic lactam compounds, a series of siderophore-conjugated monocarbams had been described.(150) A monocyclic β-lactam core renders them stable to metallo-β-lactamases, and the 1,3-dihydroxypyridinone mimics the bacteria’s natural siderophores and hijacks its iron uptake machinery for penetration into the periplasm to improve the efficacy. These monocarbams displayed excellent biochemical and cellular activity against P. aeruginosa, good hydrolytic stability, and favorable pharmacokinetics parameters. Compared with a triazole functionality, optimal physical properties (i.e., high free fraction and good hydrolytic stability) can be successfully obtained by introducing a saturated linked chain on 6-position of the HPO ring. Lactam rings were not readily hydrolyzed, while side chains more readily modified. In the optimization process, a low clearance rate and an increase of free drug concentration in the body should be maintained. Compound 91, with good free fraction levels (>20% free), hydrolytic stability (t1/2 ≥ 100 h) and cellular activity against P. aeruginosa (MIC = 0.5 μg/mL, P. aeruginosa MIC90 (n = 2) = 2 μg/mL), was identified as a lead compound.
    In conclusion, the growth of bacteria is largely influenced by iron levels in the environment, and HPOs, as strong iron chelating agents, can effectively inhibit the growth of bacteria. HPO-based macromolecules may have more potential in antibacterial treatment because of their high pFe3+ values and different LogP values in comparison with small molecular HPOs. Because they have the characteristics of potent iron chelation, hydrophilicity, and difficulty in gastrointestinal absorption and low toxicity, they have the potential for the treatment of superficial skin wound infections, ulcers, and other external infections.

    2.4. Hydroxypyridinones as Antiviral Agents

    As an important element in DNA and RNA synthetic pathways, iron affects the activation of some viral nuclear transcription factors. Studies have demonstrated that iron and oxidative stress might play an important role in the activation of HIV-1. Thus, HIV-1 replication can be inhibited by reducing iron availability.(28) Iron chelators could influence the replication of HIV in many possible paths: (1) the long terminal repeats of HIV-1 contain nuclear factor (NF)-κB response elements that regulate proviral transcription, and iron can affect the activation of NF-κB through the production of ROS;(29,151) (2) iron chelation inhibits DNA synthesis by inhibiting iron-dependent nucleotide reductase, thereby affecting HIV replication;(152) and (3) iron chelators attack viral DNA or RNA directly by inhibiting viral proliferation and the resulting apoptosis.(153,154) These mechanisms have brought iron chelators into focus as potential therapeutic antiviral agents.

    2.4.1. Bidentate HPOs

    DFP and mimosine (92) have been reported to inhibit deoxyhypusyl hydroxylase in T-lymphocytic and promonocytic cell lines by the Hanauske-Abel group as early as 1988.(155) They were able to demonstrate a decrease in the replication of HIV-1 and the biosynthesis of HIV-1-directed protein in a concentration-dependent manner. HPOs had no influence on the formation of unspliced or multispliced HIV-1 transcription. By interfering with the mRNA translation of incomplete splicing retroviruses, these compounds limit HIV-1 to the early nonreproductive phase of its reproductive cycle. The presence of HPOs selectively inhibit the biosynthesis of proteins, leading to the apoptosis of the infected cells. HPOs preferentially promote apoptosis of retrovirally infected human T lymphocytes, suggesting that they have the potential to selectively ablate HIV1-producing cells. In addition, the iron chelators DFP and DFO were found to inhibit HIV-1 replication by the iron-catalyzed inactivation of the iron chelator-complex.(30) The chelators reduced the expression of the p24 antigen in peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBL) and macrophages derived from human monocytes. Furthermore, it was found that CP502 (21a) and CP511 (21b) inhibited the replication of HIV-1 by decreasing cellular proliferation in a similar manner to that of DFO and DFP.(153) Both CP502 (IC50 = 33.3 ± 8.7 μM) and CP511 (IC50 = 20.0 ± 6.4 μM) possess a higher affinity for iron and stronger inhibition for HIV-1 than DFP (IC50 = 102.5 ± 37.4 μM) (see section 2.1.4). The inhibition of HIV-1 replication demonstrated by these chelators was achieved by inhibiting cellular proliferation rather than a direct antiviral effect.
    The combined use of HPOs and the nucleoside analogue deoxyinosine has been shown to synergistically reduce HIV in human PBL in vitro.(30)

    2.4.2. Deoxynucleoside HPOs

    Some α- and β-dideoxynucleoside derivatives with the base replaced by an HPO moiety (93–96) have been evaluated against various viruses, including vaccinia virus, HIV-1, HIV-2, herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1), and type 2 (HSV-2).(156) However, these compounds possessed no activity against any of the tested viruses except the HSVs. Compounds 93b, 94a, and 94b were found to exert only moderate activity against wild-type HSV-1 and HSV-2, and moderate activity against thymidine kinase-deficient strains of HSV-1. These activities suggest that these new nucleosides were metabolized to their 5′-triphosphates or were recognized by viral DNA polymerases.
    A series of cyclic and acyclic nucleoside analogs (95–97) derived from HPO were also investigated, but no activity was observed against HIV and only moderate activity against HSV-1 and HSV-2.(157) The absence of anti-HIV activity may arise due either to a lack of intracellular phosphorylation or to difficulties associated with crossing the cellular membrane.
    At the present time, there have been no HPOs identified that possess antiviral properties markedly superior to those of DFP.

    2.5. Hydroxypyridinones as Antiprotozoal Agents

    Malaria is a major global health problem, and there is a pressing need for the scientific community to develop new antimalarial drugs. Iron deficiency has a detrimental effect on the development of human malaria,(158) and in contrast, iron administration may exacerbate malaria.(159) In principle, therefore, iron chelators could be used to treat malaria by inhibiting iron-dependent metabolic pathways of the parasite or by forming toxic iron complexes that possess antimalarial activity.

    2.5.1. Lipophilic HPOs

    DFO demonstrated in vivo antimalarial activity in several mammalian species; however, its application is limited because of its poor absorption and short half-life.(158) The antimalarial effects of a series of HPOs have also been explored, and dose-dependent inhibition was observed in vitro.(160) Among these compounds, DFP (9), CP38 (98), and CP40 (99) failed to inhibit malaria, while the more lipophilic CP51 (11), CP94 (10), and CP96 (100) had strong inhibitory effects on malaria growth, indeed superior to DFO. These HPOs can inhibit malaria both in vitro and in vivo.(160) The prodrug concept can be utilized to overcome the disadvantage of poor oral absorption and hydrophilicity, such as CP38 ester prodrugs which can facilitate the transport of CP38 to the blood supply.(161) In order to improve the efficiency of the antimalaria activity of HPOs, nitrogen centers were introduced to HPOs in order to target acidic vacuoles, such as those found in the parasite. Compounds 101 and 102 were found to be the most promising candidates, with appropriate LogP values to facilitate their penetration into intracellular organelles while being sufficiently hydrophilic to lack the general toxicity.(162)

    2.5.2. Piperidone Analogues

    Piperidone analogues have been designed as inhibitors of Plasmodium falciparum, where they are targeted against deoxyhypusine hydroxylase (DHH).(163) DHH is an iron-dependent enzyme, and alkyl 4-oxo-piperidine-3-carboxylates are inhibitors of this enzyme and were found to possess antiplasmodium effects both in vitro and in vivo. The saturated 4-oxo-piperidine-3-monoester (103) was reported to be more efficient than 104 and the tetra- and dihydropyridone monoesters (105 and 106) in inhibiting the growth of the parasite. However, DHH7 (107) was reported to be the most potent compound in the series with an IC50 value of 1.4 μM.

    2.5.3. HPO-Chloroquine Hybrids

    In order to improve the antimalarial activity of HPOs, the synthesis of a series of DFP–chloroquine (CQ) hybrids has been investigated. HPO conjugates, such as 108 and 109, showed enhanced antiplasmodial activities when compared to that of DFP, but were less active than CQ alone.(164)108 and 109 were also tested against Trypanosoma brucei, Trypanosoma cruzi, and Leishmania infantum, 108 being the most potent conjugate. The antitrypanosomal activity of 108 was 4-fold greater than that of CQ.
    Moreover, Chibale’s group synthesized a series of non-cytotoxic 4-aminoquinoline-HPO hybrids and were tested against CQ-resistant (K1 and W2) and CQ-sensitive (3D7) strains of Plasmodium falciparum.(165) These hybrid molecules were found to inhibit β-hematin synthesis. The 3-benzylated (110 and 111) and 3-hydroxy (112) HPO hybrids all showed greater β-hematin inhibition activity than that of the corresponding HPO and CQ alone. For the most part, 3-hydroxy HPO hybrids were observed to be less efficient in the inhibition of β-hematin formation. The antiplasmodial activity of the hybrids was enhanced due to accumulation in the digestive vacuole mediated by the CQ moiety. The most promising hybrids inhibiting strains K1, 3D7, and W2 were 110 (0.13, 0.004, and 0.1 μM), 111 (0.08, 0.01, and 0.02 μM), and 112 (0.07, 0.03, and 0.08 μM), respectively.
    An extension of this work led to the identification of 113 and 114, which possess antimalarial activity against Plasmodium falciparum CQ-sensitive (3D7 and D10) and CQ-resistant strains (K1 and Dd2).(166) The IC50 values were 0.064 and 0.047 μM (113), 0.041 and 0.122 μM (114), 0.505 and 0.463 μM (113), 0.089 and 0.076 μM (114), respectively (Table 2). Both compounds were more active than CQ in vitro, but the in vivo pharmacokinetics evaluation of these hybrids showed a low oral bioavailability. When dosed intravenously, compound 114 could reduce parasitemia levels and showed improved pharmacokinetics properties in P. berghei infected mice. Thus, these HPO-CQ hybrids need additional structural modification in order to improve their in vivo efficacy.
    Table 2. In vitro IC50 values (μM) of Compounds 113 and 114
     sensitive strainsresistant strains
    compound3D7D10K1Dd2
    1130.064 ± 0.020.047 ± 0.010.505 ± 0.100.463 ± 0.12
    1140.041 ± 0.020.122 ± 0.030.089 ± 0.010.076 ± 0.01
    CQ0.019 ± 0.000.023 ± 0.000.279 ± 0.0020.180 ± 0.01
    In summary, structural optimization of HPOs can enhance antimalarial activity, and conjugation of the HPO iron chelator to a second bioactive component presents a promising antiparasitic strategy.

    2.6. Hydroxypyridinones as Anti-Inflammatory Agents

    Many inflammatory signals are regulated by hepcidin gene expression, and one of the most significant effects of inflammation is its effect on iron transport.(26) Inflammation will stimulate the upregulation of hepcidin, leading to the downregulation of FPN, the increase of iron storage, and the release of inflammatory factors.(11) Iron plays an essential role in the regulation of inflammatory processes and hosts immuno-surveillance by regulating the proliferation, differentiation, activation, and apoptosis of B, T, and NK cells; by interfering with cytokine activities and the cell-mediated immune effector pathways; and by catalyzing the formation of toxic radicals for the host defense.(26) Many studies have shown that iron chelators can block the production of inflammatory cytokines and attenuate lipid peroxidation and the production of ROS.(167)

    2.6.1. Bidentate HPOs

    In 2001, Ozturk and co-workers described the synthesis and structural and pharmacological properties of two new HPO derivatives (115, 116) and the 1,2,5-trisubstituted series (117, 118).(168,169) Analgesic and anti-inflammatory activities were investigated by acetic acid-induced writhing syndrome and carrageenan rat paw edema tests with acetylsalicylic acid and indomethacin as comparison compounds. All compounds exhibited higher analgesic activity than acetylsalicylic acid and showed higher anti-inflammatory activities than indomethacin. 116d and 118c were identified as the most promising compounds. Furthermore, compound 118c showed almost no ulcerogenic activity when compared to indomethacin.
    The pharmacological properties of HPO derivatives suggested that they could inhibit the synthesis of prostaglandin E and arachidonic acid. However, the most promising aspect of their analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects is probably due to their iron-chelating properties.

    2.6.2. DIBI

    Lehmann and co-workers have investigated the anti-inflammatory efficacy of a polymeric HPO iron chelator (DIBI, 89b) in experimental sepsis and local and systemic models of endotoxin-induced uveitis (EIU).(170,171) DIBI is a novel iron chelator comprising nine pyridinone chelating monomers copolymerized to vinylpyrrolidone. In experimental sepsis, DIBI-A (m = 9), DIBI-B and MAHMP (89a, the chelating monomer) were compared. DIBI-B reduced the number of adhering leukocytes in submucosal collecting venules in endotoxemic mice by 68% and restored the functional capillary density (FCD) in the intestinal muscle layer. These results indicated that DIBI-B reduced leukocyte recruitment, improved FCD, and prevented mucosal damage in experimental endotoxemia, outperforming the other two iron chelators tested. DIBI-B’s ability to selectively bind iron, while remaining nontoxic and biocompatible renders it a candidate drug for further investigation. Recently, in local and systemic models of EIU, DIBI was demonstrated to possess anti-inflammatory properties by decreasing leukocyte adhesion and by improving the FCD in the iridial microcirculation without local adverse effects in the eye.(171)

    2.7. Hydroxypyridinones as Anticancer Agents

    Overloaded iron in the body is associated with the development and progression of cancer.(172) The associated iron generated free radicals can promote DNA strand breakage, oncogene activation, and tumor suppressor gene suppression.(173) Many iron metabolic-related proteins are also involved in the development, proliferation, and metastasis of malignant tumors.(33) Cancer cells require a larger amount of iron than normal cells, which is manifested in the overexpression of TFR1, DMT1, and hepcidin to absorb more iron into cells or low-expression of FNP and HEPH to increase intracellular iron.(174,175) The synthesis of DNA in tumor cells also requires iron-dependent ribonucleotide reductase to catalyze the reduction of RNA to DNA.(176) This increased dependence of cancer cells on iron indicates that iron chelation could be an effective cancer treatment strategy.(177,178)

    2.7.1. Bidentate HPOs

    Hoyes and co-workers studied the synchronization and growth inhibition of the leukemia cell cycle by HPO iron chelators.(179) Both HPOs and DFO inhibited the cell cycle in a dose-dependent manner, but when the chelators were subsequently removed, the HPO-treated cells cascaded into the S phase synchronously, while the DFO-treated cells resumed cycling in an asynchronous manner. HPOs were clearly superior to DFO as cell cycle synchronizers, and this may be a helpful adjuvant in cell cycle-specific therapy. In vitro studies also found that iron chelators, such as DFO and DFP, displayed different inhibitory effects on the proliferation of nerve tumor cell lines and human liver cancer cells.(180,181) It has also been suggested that iron chelators may also inhibit the proliferation and apoptosis of human cervical cancer cells, which could occur in a time- and dose-dependent manner, thereby inhibiting the growth and inducing apoptosis of human papillomavirus (HPV)-positive cancer cells.(182) The efficiency of CP411 liver cell uptake and its inhibition on tumor cell proliferation were both greater than those of DFP. CP411 was found to have a significant effect on the protection of liver cells from the toxicity of iron overload and the inhibition of tumor cell proliferation.(183) The polyamine-iron chelator conjugate 119 was at least 230 times more potent than the parent HPO ligand in inhibiting the growth of L1210 mouse leukemia cells, providing a promising indicator for further studies on the effects of iron chelators on tumor cell growth.(184)

    2.7.2. Hydroxypyridin-2-ones

    Hydroxypyridin-2-ones possess antitumor activity, the enzymes involved in the regulation of protein phosphorylation being the targets for cancer treatment. In particular, the protein phosphatases of the Cdc25 family have attracted attention because of their important role in cell cycle regulation. TMC-69-6H (120) is an inhibitor of phosphatase VHR, tyrosine protein phosphatase PTB1B.(185)
    The antitumor activities of 3-[(4-hydroxy-6-methyl-2(1H)-pyridinones)-3-yl]-4- substituted-(1H)-1,2,4-triazole-5-thiones (121 and 122) were demonstrated in vitro to be highly inhibitory against KB cells, and compound 122 was highly inhibitory against Bel-7402 cells.(186) SAR showed that the compounds with electron-withdrawing substitutes (such as F, Cl, Br) on the aryl ring exhibited more potent activities than those with electron-donating substitutes. Compounds with the electron-withdrawing substitutes at the meta position had activity superior to those with substitutes at the para position.
    ERCC1-XPF endonuclease plays an important role in nucleotide resection repair (NER) and interchain cross-linking repair (ICR). Therefore, inhibition of ERCC1-XPF endonuclease may improve the efficacy of chemotherapy drugs such as cisplatin. 3-Hydroxypyridin-2-ones are able to inhibit ERCC1-XPF, compounds 123 and 124 being the most promising compounds.(187)
    HPO chelators are rarely investigated as antitumor agents, but further investigation on these compounds has potential.

    2.8. Hydroxypyridinones as Iron-Containing Metalloenzyme Inhibitors

    Metalloenzymes account for at least one-third of all proteases and utilize a wide variety of metal ion cofactors for their electron transfer, catalytic, structural, or other critical functions.(188) Metalloenzyme inhibitors can be linked to the treatment of a number of diseases, such as cancer, arthritis, atherosclerosis, and heart disease. One of the major targets for metalloenzyme inhibition are the non-heme iron-containing enzymes such as cyclooxygenase, lipoxygenase, ribonucleotide reductase, aromatic hydroxylases, and ferrochelatase.(189)

    2.8.1. Ribonucleotide Reductase Inhibitors

    The inhibition of ribonucleotide reductase renders it possible to synchronize cell cycling, which is associated with the combination of chemotherapy for tumors. The anticancer effect of HPOs reported by Hoyes was largely due to the inhibition of ribonucleotide reductase.(179) Subsequently, they simultaneously examined the relationship between intracellular iron chelation and the rate of clearance and regeneration of ribonucleotide reductase in intact human leukemia K562 cells using electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) technology.(190) HPOs (DFP and CP94) remove the tyrosyl radical more quickly than DFO because of the depletion of the intracellular iron pools, which is necessary to regenerate the active enzyme. This property is attributed to the increased membrane permeability of the unchelated form of HPOs. Hydrophobic and/or uncharged HPO chelators will rapidly gain access to the cell. Effective iron mobilization also requires that the iron-chelate complex be able to efflux from the cell. Thus, an ideal chelator for clinical use will be hydrophobic and neutral in both the chelated and unchelated forms and thus able to mobilize iron from cells quickly.

    2.8.2. 5-Lipoxygenase and Tyrosine Hydroxylase Inhibitors

    5-Lipoxygenase (5-LOX) is a non-heme iron-containing enzyme catalyzing the oxidation of polyunsaturated fatty acids to produce hydroperoxides. The first two steps in the conversion of arachidonic acid to leukotriene A4 is one such example.(191) Hider and co-workers investigated the SAR of 1- and 2-substituted HPOs (126–128) with 5-LOX and ribonucleotide reductase compared with DFO and the non-iron-binding analogue Ome-25 (125).(191,192) The molecular dimensions, lipophilicity, and iron-binding constant had critical effects on the ability of these chelators to inhibit 5-LOX and ribonucleotide reductase.
