      103. 103
        Gaeta, A.; Molina-Holgado, F.; Kong, X. L.; Salvage, S.; Fakih, S.; Francis, P. T.; Williams, R. J.; Hider, R. C. Synthesis, physical-chemical characterisation and biological evaluation of novel 2-amido-3-hydroxypyridin-4(1H)-ones: iron chelators with the potential for treating Alzheimer’s disease. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2011, 19 (3), 1285– 1297,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmc.2010.12.007
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        103
        Synthesis, physical-chemical characterization and biological evaluation of novel 2-amido-3-hydroxypyridin-4(1H)-ones: Iron chelators with the potential for treating Alzheimer's disease
        Gaeta, Alessandra; Molina-Holgado, Francisco; Kong, Xiao L.; Salvage, Sarah; Fakih, Sarah; Francis, Paul T.; Williams, Robert J.; Hider, Robert C.
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2011), 19 (3), 1285-1297CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A novel class of 2-amido-3-hydroxypyridin-4-one iron chelators is described. These compds. have been designed to behave as suitable mol. probes which will improve our knowledge of the role of iron in neurodegenerative conditions. Neurodegenerative disorders, such as Alzheimer's disease (AD) and Parkinson disease (PD), can be considered as diverse pathol. conditions sharing crit. metabolic processes such as protein aggregation and oxidative stress. Interestingly, both these metabolic alterations seem to be assocd. with the involvement of metal ions, including iron. Iron chelation is therefore a potential therapeutic approach. The physico-chem. (pKa, pFe3+ and log P) and biol. properties (inhibition of iron-contg. enzymes) of these chelators have been investigated in order to obtain a suitable profile for the treatment of neurodegenerative conditions. Studies with neuronal cell cultures confirm that the new iron chelators are neuroprotective against β-amyloid-induced toxicity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtlKks7o%253D&md5=af9ab71746b35530f0fc01072428d05b
      104. 104
        Workman, D. G.; Tsatsanis, A.; Lewis, F. W.; Boyle, J. P.; Mousadoust, M.; Hettiarachchi, N. T.; Hunter, M.; Peers, C. S.; Tetard, D.; Duce, J. A. Protection from neurodegeneration in the 6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA) model of Parkinson’s with novel 1-hydroxypyridin-2-one metal chelators. Metallomics 2015, 7 (5), 867– 876,  DOI: 10.1039/C4MT00326H
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        104
        Protection from neurodegeneration in the 6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA) model of Parkinson's with novel 1-hydroxypyridin-2-one metal chelators
        Workman, David G.; Tsatsanis, Andrew; Lewis, Frank W.; Boyle, John P.; Mousadoust, Maryam; Hettiarachchi, Nishani T.; Hunter, Michael; Peers, Chris S.; Tetard, David; Duce, James A.
        Metallomics (2015), 7 (5), 867-876CODEN: METAJS; ISSN:1756-591X. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Brain iron accumulation has been assocd. with inciting the generation of oxidative stress in a host of chronic neurol. diseases, including Parkinson's disease. Using the catecholaminergic neurotoxin 6-hydroxydopamine to lesion cellular dopaminergic pathways as a model of Parkinson's disease in culture, a selection of 1-hydroxypyridin-2-one (1,2-HOPO) metal chelators were synthesized and their neuroprotective properties were compared to the 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one; deferiprone (3,4-HOPO; DFP). Protection against 6-OHDA and iron insult by the novel compds. 6 and 9 was comparable to DFP. Iron assocd. changes by 6-OHDA imply that the neuroprotective capacity of these compds. are due to chelation of the neuronal labile iron pool and the requirement of the iron binding moiety of compd. 6 for efficacy supported this hypothesis. In conclusion, two novel 1,2-HOPO's and DFP have comparable neuroprotection against Parkinsonian-assocd. neurotoxins and supports the continued development of hydroxypyridinone compds. as a non-toxic therapeutic agent in the treatment of neurodegenerative disease.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXkt1Onu78%253D&md5=757d5a5f8aec3199931886c689f90723
      105. 105
        Shin, R. W.; Kruck, T. P. A.; Murayama, H.; Kitamoto, T. A novel trivalent cation chelator Feralex dissociates binding of aluminum and iron associated with hyperphosphorylated τ of Alzheimer’s disease. Brain Res. 2003, 961, 139– 146,  DOI: 10.1016/S0006-8993(02)03893-3
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        105
        A novel trivalent cation chelator Feralex dissociates binding of aluminum and iron associated with hyperphosphorylated τ of Alzheimer's disease
        Shin, Ryong-Woon; Kruck, Theo P. A.; Murayama, Harunobu; Kitamoto, Tetsuyuki
        Brain Research (2003), 961 (1), 139-146CODEN: BRREAP; ISSN:0006-8993. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        Aluminum (Al(III)) and iron (Fe(III)) are reported to accumulate in neurofibrillary tangles of the Alzheimer's disease (AD) brain. In these lesions Al (III) and Fe (III) bind with hyperphosphorylated τ (PHFτ), the major constituent of the lesions, and induce its aggregation. It is thought that inhibition and dissocn. of such Al (III)/Fe (III) binding assocd. with PHFτ could slow or halt the τ-related neurofibrillary degeneration in patients with AD. A study, using a previously developed in vitro system in which Al (III) and Fe (III) interact with PHFτ on AD brain sections and on immunoblot membranes showed that the potent Al (III)/Fe (III) chelator desferrioxamine elicited Al (III) chelation when subjected to autoclave heating. Here, the ability of a recently developed chem. chelator Feralex-G to remove PHFτ-bound Al (III)/Fe (III), using reaction conditions at 37, was examd. and compared with that of desferrioxamine. Chelation of Fe(III) was achieved by both compds. with no discernible difference in their chelating ability. In contrast, in the present system, the two chelators gave a different Al (III) chelation response. When incubated at 37, desferrioxamine failed to attain notable Al (III) chelation, while Feralex-G displayed efficient Al (III) chelation. Thus, when considering competitive Al (III) removal from brain PHFτ, Feralex-G is a stronger chelator for Al(III) than desferrioxamine. The efficient Al (III) chelation attainable by Feralex-G adds wt. to its potential clin. usefulness as a medicine in the aluminum/iron chelation therapy for patients with AD.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXivVGitg%253D%253D&md5=c0abd148b3a9788775968eaac468f098
      106. 106
        Schugar, H.; Green, D. E.; Bowen, M. L.; Scott, L. E.; Storr, T.; Bohmerle, K.; Thomas, F.; Allen, D. D.; Lockman, P. R.; Merkel, M.; Thompson, K. H.; Orvig, C. Combating Alzheimer’s disease with multifunctional molecules designed for metal passivation. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2007, 46 (10), 1716– 1718,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.200603866

        106
        Combating Alzheimer's disease with multifunctional molecules designed for metal passivation
        Schugar, Harvey; Green, David E.; Bowen, Meryn L.; Scott, Lauren E.; Storr, Tim; Bohmerle, Karin; Thomas, Fancy; Allen, David D.; Lockman, Paul R.; Merkel, Michael; Thompson, Katherine H.; Orvig, Chris
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (10), 1716-1718CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A trifunctional approach: 3-hydroxy-4-pyridinones that contain phenol groups for antioxidant functionality are further elaborated with pendant glucosyl moieties for improved blood-brain barrier targeting (R = Ph, 4-hydroxyphenyl). Glycosidase removal of the carbohydrate substituents gives ligands that are ready to passivate excess metal ions, esp. copper and zinc, in the brain. These mols. are potential prodrugs for treatment of neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's disease.

      108. 108
        Scott, L. E.; Telpoukhovskaia, M.; Rodríguez-Rodríguez, C.; Merkel, M.; Bowen, M. L.; Page, B. D. G.; Green, D. E.; Storr, T.; Thomas, F.; Allen, D. D.; Lockman, P. R.; Patrick, B. O.; Adam, M. J.; Orvig, C. N-Aryl-substituted 3-(β-D-glucopyranosyloxy)-2-methyl-4(1H)-pyridinones as agents for Alzheimer’s therapy. Chem. Sci. 2011, 2 (4), 642– 648,  DOI: 10.1039/C0SC00544D
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        108
        N-Aryl-substituted 3-(β-D-glucopyranosyloxy)-2-methyl-4(1H)-pyridinones as agents for Alzheimer's therapy
        Scott, Lauren E.; Telpoukhovskaia, Maria; Rodriguez-Rodriguez, Cristina; Merkel, Michael; Bowen, Meryn L.; Page, Brent D. G.; Green, David E.; Storr, Tim; Thomas, Fancy; Allen, David D.; Lockman, Paul R.; Patrick, Brian O.; Adam, Michael J.; Orvig, Chris
        Chemical Science (2011), 2 (4), 642-648CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Mols. designed to sequester, redistribute and/or remove metal ions are attractive therapeutic agents in neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease. The multifactorial nature of the condition and the generally poor target specificity assocd. with metal ion-binding therapy has led to the development of multifunctional 3-hydroxy-4-(1H)-pyridinone pro-ligands. The excellent qualities of the basic 3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone framework as a low toxicity metal chelator and an antioxidant, as well as its antibacterial and analgesic properties among other functions, inspired us to functionalize it with a framework derived from thioflavin-T, the well-known traditional dye used as a marker to detect amyloid deposits in tissue sections. Thus 2-methyl-3-hydroxy-1-(4-dimethylaminophenyl)-4(1H)-pyridinone (HL1), 2-methyl-3-hydroxy-1-(4-methylaminophenyl)-4(1H)-pyridinone (HL2), 1-(4-aminophenyl)-3-hydroxy-2-methyl-4(1H)-pyridinone (HL3), 1-(6-benzothiazolyl)-3-hydroxy-2-methyl-4(1H)-pyridinone (HL4), 1-(2-benzothiazolyl)-3-hydroxy-2-methyl-4(1H)-pyridinone (HL5) and 2-methyl-3-hydroxy-1-[4-(4-bromophenyl)-2-thiazolyl]-4(1H)-pyridinone (HL6) were obtained. Glycosylation, as well as incorporation of structures mimicking those of known amyloid imaging agents, may target drug action to the site of interest, the metal-overloaded amyloid plaques in the Alzheimer's brain. The pro-ligands were assessed for their antioxidant activity, cytotoxicity and ability to interfere with metal ion-induced amyloid peptide aggregation to screen promising lead compds. Finally, in a brain uptake study with a radiolabeled glucoconjugate pyridinone, 3-(β-D-glucopyranosyloxy)-1-[4-(4-[125I]iodophenyl)-2-thiazolyl]-2-methyl-4(1H)-pyridinone ([125I]-GL7) was shown to cross the blood-brain barrier using an in situ rat brain perfusion technique.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXjtFGltb4%253D&md5=81d4f0e8fd01b8ca8aa1247c16c1a230

        Roy, S.; Preston, J. E.; Hider, R. C.; Ma, Y. M. Glucosylated deferiprone and its brain uptake: implications for developing glucosylated hydroxypyridinone analogues intended to cross the blood-brain barrier. J. Med. Chem. 2010, 53 (15), 5886– 5889,  DOI: 10.1021/jm100380k

        109
        Glucosylated Deferiprone and Its Brain Uptake: Implications for Developing Glucosylated Hydroxypyridinone Analogues Intended to Cross the Blood-Brain Barrier
        Roy, Sourav; Preston, Jane E.; Hider, Robert C.; Ma, Yong Min
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2010), 53 (15), 5886-5889CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        This report presents that Deferiprone, the only clin. used 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one (HPO), is able to penetrate the blood-brain barrier (BBB) in guinea pigs, whereas its glucosylated analog is unable to do so. This finding is contrary to published information suggesting that the glucosylation of HPOs is a viable means of enhancing the brain uptake of this group of compds.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXovFemsLg%253D&md5=588a4a077d3ecb7b28b1ff4e670eaa76
      110. 110
        Telpoukhovskaia, M. A.; Patrick, B. O.; Rodriguez-Rodriguez, C.; Orvig, C. Exploring the multifunctionality of thioflavin- and deferiprone-based molecules as acetylcholinesterase inhibitors for potential application in Alzheimer’s disease. Mol. BioSyst. 2013, 9 (4), 792– 805,  DOI: 10.1039/c3mb25600f
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        110
        Exploring the multifunctionality of thioflavin- and deferiprone-based molecules as acetylcholinesterase inhibitors for potential application in Alzheimer's disease
        Telpoukhovskaia, Maria A.; Patrick, Brian O.; Rodriguez-Rodriguez, Cristina; Orvig, Chris
        Molecular BioSystems (2013), 9 (4), 792-805CODEN: MBOIBW; ISSN:1742-2051. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that affects millions of people worldwide. With no prevention or cure available, this progressive disease has a significant impact on society - dementia patients and their caretakers, healthcare systems, and the economy. Previously, we have reported initial developments of multifunctional drug candidates for AD based on two scaffolds - thioflavin-T and deferiprone. Individually, these mols. have shown several favorable functionalities, including dissocn. of toxic amyloid-β aggregates, antioxidant and/or metal chelating ability that can pacify reactive oxygen species, plaque targeting, and blood-brain barrier penetration. In this work, the two scaffolds are augmented with a new functionality - acetylcholinesterase inhibition. This functionality is incorporated by derivatization with a carbamate group, which is the active group in some AD drugs currently in the market. We present the rationale for designing three novel compds., their synthesis and characterization, including X-ray crystallog. data, and encouraging results from in vitro and computational acetylcholinesterase inhibition studies. Also, we evaluate the compds. as potential drug candidates by Lipinski's rules and cytotoxicity studies in a neuronal cell line. Overall, we demonstrate the feasibility of improving on two well established scaffolds, as well as show in vitro efficacy plus initial mode of action and biol. compatibility data.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXjsVKrsL0%253D&md5=51b2998a266314ba4186cc52bffedb14
      111. 111
        Telpoukhovskaia, M. A.; Patrick, B. O.; Rodriguez-Rodriguez, C.; Orvig, C. In silico to in vitro screening of hydroxypyridinones as acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2016, 26 (6), 1624– 1628,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmcl.2016.01.080
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        111
        In silico to in vitro screening of hydroxypyridinones as acetylcholinesterase inhibitors
        Telpoukhovskaia, Maria A.; Patrick, Brian O.; Rodriguez-Rodriguez, Cristina; Orvig, Chris
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2016), 26 (6), 1624-1628CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The authors have previously shown the improved acetylcholinesterase inhibitory activity of a model hydroxypyridinone compd. transforming the hydroxyl group on the main ring into an N,N-dimethylcarbamate group; in the course of that study the authors developed a computational model to screen compds. for enzymic activity. Herein the authors report development of second generation libraries. Candidates that adhere to drug-like criteria from a virtual library of compds. were tested using computational docking studies. Synthesis and characterization of chosen test compds. and their acetylcholinesterase inhibitory activity are presented.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XisValsrs%253D&md5=40bb05a0dd6ab64d40e3b816b53dc555

        3,5-Disubstituted-4-hydroxyphenyls Linked to 3-Hydroxy-2-methyl-4(1H)-pyridinone: Potent Inhibitors of Lipid Peroxidation and Cell Toxicity
        Bebbington, David; Monck, Nathaniel J. T.; Gaur, Suneel; Palmer, Alan M.; Benwell, Karen; Harvey, Victoria; Malcolm, Craig S.; Porter, Richard H. P.

        Sheng, R.; Tang, L.; Jiang, L.; Hong, L.; Shi, Y.; Zhou, N.; Hu, Y. Novel 1-phenyl-3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone derivatives as multifunctional agents for the therapy of Alzheimer’s disease. ACS Chem. Neurosci. 2016, 7 (1), 69– 81,  DOI: 10.1021/acschemneuro.5b00224

        113
        Novel 1-Phenyl-3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone Derivatives as Multifunctional Agents for the Therapy of Alzheimer's Disease
        Sheng, Rong; Tang, Li; Jiang, Liu; Hong, Lingjuan; Shi, Ying; Zhou, Naiming; Hu, Yongzhou
        ACS Chemical Neuroscience (2016), 7 (1), 69-81CODEN: ACNCDM; ISSN:1948-7193. (American Chemical Society)
        A series of novel 1-phenyl-3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone derivs. were designed and synthesized as multifunctional agents for Alzheimer's disease (AD) therapy through incorporation of 3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone moiety from deferiprone into the scaffold of H3 receptor antagonists. Most of these new compds. displayed designed quadruple functions, H3 receptor antagonism, Aβ aggregation inhibition, metal ion chelation, and radical scavenging. Esp., the most promising compd. I displayed nanomolar IC50 values in H3 receptor antagonism with high selectivity, efficient capability to interrupt the formation of Aβ1-42 fibrils, good copper and iron chelating properties, and more potent 2,2'-azino-bis(3-ethyl-benzothiazoline-6-sulfonic acid) radical cation (ABTS•+) scavenging activity than Trolox. Further biol. evaluation revealed that it did not show obvious cytotoxicity and hERG potassium channel inhibition at micromolar concn. In addn., compd. I demonstrated suitable pharmacokinetic properties and acceptable blood-brain barrier permeability in vivo. All these results indicate that compd. I is a potential multifunctional candidate for AD therapy.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhs1OhurnJ&md5=66c8440d6a02d18c7cbbd948f5b97540

        Arduino, D.; Silva, D.; Cardoso, S. M.; Chaves, S.; Oliveira, C. R.; Santos, M. A. New hydroxypyridinone iron-chelators as potential anti-neurodegenerative drugs. Front. Biosci. 2008, 13, 6763– 6774,  DOI: 10.2741/3187
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        114
        New hydroxypyridinone iron-chelators as potential anti-neurodegenerative drugs
        Arduino, Daniela; Silva, Daniel; Cardoso, Sandra M.; Chaves, Silvia; Oliveira, Catarina R.; Santos, M. Amelia
        Frontiers in Bioscience (2008), 13 (), 6763-6774CODEN: FRBIF6; ISSN:1093-4715. (Frontiers in Bioscience)
        The neuroprotective action of a set of new hydroxypyridinone-based (3,4-HP) compds. (A, B and C), which are iron chelators extra-functionalized with a propargylamino group for potential MAO-B inhibition, was evaluated after cell treatment with MPP+ (an in vivo inducer of parkinsonism) and Abeta1-40 and/or Abeta1-42 peptides. Our results show that all these compds. improved cell viability in cells treated with MPP+ and Abeta1-40 peptide or Abeta1-42 peptide. In order to evaluate the cellular mechanisms underlying the activity of these compds., we studied their protective role in caspase activation All compds. tested were able to prevent MPP+ and Brefeldin A induced caspase-2 activation. They also sowed quite effective in the inhibition of caspase-4 and caspase-3 activity, an effector caspase in the apoptotic process. Finally, detection of apoptotic-like cell death after cell exposure to MPP+ was also performed by TUNEL assay. Our results demonstrated that all tested compds. prevented DNA fragmentation by decreasing TUNEL pos. cells. A, B and C were more effective than DFP (a 3,4-HP iron-chelating agent in clin. use) in MPP+ induced cell death. Therefore, these results evidenced a neuroprotective and antiapoptotic role for the compds. studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXnsVOitbo%253D&md5=a84b7def01a9234f15ac198039881610
      115. 115
        Nunes, A.; Marques, S. M.; Quintanova, C.; Silva, D. F.; Cardoso, S. M.; Chaves, S.; Santos, M. A. Multifunctional iron-chelators with protective roles against neurodegenerative diseases. Dalton. Trans. 2013, 42 (17), 6058– 6073,  DOI: 10.1039/c3dt50406a
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        115
        Multifunctional iron-chelators with protective roles against neurodegenerative diseases
        Nunes, Andreia; Marques, Sergio M.; Quintanova, Catarina; Silva, Diana F.; Cardoso, Sandra M.; Chaves, Silvia; Santos, M. Amelia
        Dalton Transactions (2013), 42 (17), 6058-6073CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The multifactorial nature of Alzheimer's disease (AD), and the absence of a disease modifying drug, makes the development of new multifunctional drugs an attractive therapeutic strategy. Taking into account the hallmarks of AD patient brains, such as low levels of acetylcholine, misfolding of proteins and assocd. beta-amyloid (Aβ) aggregation, oxidative stress and metal dyshomeostasis, the authors have developed a series of compds. that merge three different approaches: metal attenuation, anti-Aβ aggregation and anti-acetylcholinesterase activity. Therefore, 3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone (3,4-HP) and benzothiazole mol. moieties were selected as starting frameworks due to their well known affinity for iron and Aβ peptides, resp. The linkers between these two main functional groups were selected on the basis of virtual screening, so that the final mol. could further inhibit the acetylcholinesterase, responsible for the cholinergic losses. The authors describe herein the design and synthesis of the new hybrid compds., followed by the assessment of soln. properties, namely iron chelation and anti-oxidant capacity. The compds. were bioassayed for their capacity to inhibit AChE, as well as self- and Zn mediated-Aβ1-42 aggregation. Finally, the authors assessed their effects on the viability of neuronal cells stressed with Aβ42.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXlt1agu7c%253D&md5=67cb5814ab29cbe487b22f0fdb443bef

        Telpoukhovskaia, M. A.; Rodriguez-Rodriguez, C.; Cawthray, J. F.; Scott, L. E.; Page, B. D.; Ali-Torres, J.; Sodupe, M.; Bailey, G. A.; Patrick, B.         3-Hydroxy-4-pyridinone derivatives as metal ion and amyloid binding agents
        Telpoukhovskaia, Maria A.; Rodriguez-Rodriguez, Cristina; Cawthray, Jacqueline F.; Scott, Lauren E.; Page, Brent D. G.; Ali-Torres, Jorge; Sodupe, Mariona; Bailey, Gwendolyn A.; Patrick, Brian O.; Orvig, Chris
        Metallomics (2014), 6 (2), 249-262CODEN: METAJS; ISSN:1756-591X. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Metal ions have been implicated in several neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's disease, as their dyshomeostasis may lead to prodn. of reactive oxygen species as well as increased toxicity of amyloid protein aggregates. In this work, we present design and synthesis of three novel multifunctional hydroxypyridinone ligands, HL11, HL12, and HL13, bearing benzothiazole and benzoxazole functionalities. We study the ability of these compds. to bind metal ions Cu(II), Zn(II), and Fe(III), as well as their antioxidant activity and cytotoxicity. Addnl., we det. the pro-ligands' (compds. prior to chelation) propensity to target amyloid protein. Through these studies we det. the effect of combining amyloid- and metal-binding functionalities within the HPO scaffold on different aspects of AD pathol.

        3-Hydroxy-4-pyridinone derivatives designed for fluorescence studies to determine interaction with amyloid protein as well as cell permeability
        Telpoukhovskaia, Maria A.; Cawthray, Jacqueline F.; Rodriguez-Rodriguez, Cristina; Scott, Lauren E.; Page, Brent D. G.; Patrick, Brian O.; Orvig, Chris
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2015), 25 (17), 3654-3657CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Finding a cure for Alzheimer's disease is an urgent goal. Multifunctional metal binders are used to elucidate its pathol. features and investigated as potential therapeutics. The use of physicochem. and TD-DFT calcns. constituted successful strategy in the design of 1-(4-(benzo[d]oxazol-2-yl)phenyl)-3-hydroxy-2-methylpyridin-4(1H)-one (HL21) and 1-(4-(benzo[d]thiazol-2-yl)phenyl)-3-hydroxy-2-methylpyridin-4(1H)-one (HL22). We report the synthesis and full characterization of these compds., including X-ray crystallog. Using fluorescent signal as the readout, it was detd. that HL22 interacts with amyloid-beta protein fibrils, and permeates into bEnd.3 cells used as a mimic of the blood-brain barrier. This provides the first example of direct investigation of our hydroxypyridinone compds. within a biol. setting.

        Identification of 2-substituted benzothiazole derivatives as triple-functional agents with potential for AD therapy
        Jiang, Liu; Zhang, Minkui; Tang, Li; Weng, Qinjie; Shen, Yanhong; Hu, Yongzhou; Sheng, Rong
        RSC Advances (2016), 6 (21), 17318-17327CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A novel series of 2-substituted benzothiazole derivs. as MTDLs were designed and synthesized for AD therapy using pharmacophore-combine strategy. The benzothiazole moiety from ThT and the HPO moiety from deferiprone were connected with vinyl linker to achieve target compds. The biol. evaluation results revealed that the majority of them demonstrated desirable triple functions by interfering with Aβ aggregation, oxidative stress and metal dyshomeostasis simultaneously. The two most attractive compds. 9c and 9i exhibited excellent self-Aβ1-42 aggregation inhibitory activity, efficient ABTṠ + scavenging activity, potent biometals chelating properties, as well as disaggregation activity against previous formed Aβ1-42 fibrils. In addn. to these advantages, both of them displayed no cytotoxicity to human glioma U251 cells up to 50 μM, thereby meriting further investigation.

        Xu, P.; Zhang, M.; Sheng, R.; Ma, Y. Synthesis and biological evaluation of deferiprone-resveratrol hybrids as antioxidants, Aβ1–42 aggregation inhibitors and metal-chelating agents for Alzheimer’s disease. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2017, 127, 174– 186,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2016.12.045

        119
        Synthesis and biological evaluation of deferiprone-resveratrol hybrids as antioxidants, Aβ1-42 aggregation inhibitors and metal-chelating agents for Alzheimer's disease
        Xu, Ping; Zhang, Minkui; Sheng, Rong; Ma, Yongmin
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2017), 127 (), 174-186CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        A series of deferiprone-resveratrol hybrids have been designed and synthesized as multitarget-directed ligands (MTDLs) through merging the chelating moiety 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one into the structure of resveratrol, a natural antioxidant agent and β-amyloid peptide (Aβ) aggregation inhibitor. The in vitro biol. evaluation revealed that most of these newly synthesized compds. exhibited good inhibitory activity against self-induced Aβ1-42 aggregation, excellent antioxidant activity and potent metal chelating capability. Compds. I (R1 = H, R2 = OH) and I (R1 = Me, R2 = OEt) were identified as the most promising MTDLs with triple functions, possessing micromolar IC50 values for Aβ1-42 aggregation inhibition, greater 2,2'-azino-bis(3-ethylbenzthiazoline-6-sulfonic acid) (ABTS•+) scavenging activity than Trolox and similar pFe(III) values to that of deferiprone.

        Chand, K.; Rajeshwari; Candeias, E.; Cardoso, S. M.; Chaves, S.; Santos, M. A. Tacrine-deferiprone hybrids as multi-target-directed metal chelators against Alzheimer’s disease: a two-in-one drug. Metallomics 2018, 10 (10), 1460– 1475,  DOI: 10.1039/C8MT00143J
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        120
        Tacrine-deferiprone hybrids as multi-target-directed metal chelators against Alzheimer's disease: a two-in-one drug
        Chand, Karam; Rajeshwari; Candeias, Emanuel; Cardoso, Sandra M.; Chaves, Silvia; Santos, M. Amelia
        Metallomics (2018), 10 (10), 1460-1475CODEN: METAJS; ISSN:1756-591X. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a severe age-dependent neurodegenerative disorder affecting several million people worldwide. So far, there is no adequate medication to prevent or slow down the progression of the disease, only medication with palliative effects allowing temporary symptomatic reliefs. As part of our continuing efforts into the development of innovative drugs following a polypharmacol. strategy, we decided to use a former anti-AD palliative drug (tacrine) and to reposition it by hybridization with a metal chelating drug (deferiprone, DFP). This combination endows the hybrids with good capacity to inhibit acetylcholinesterase (low micromolar range) and self-/Cu-induced Aβ aggregation (up to ca. 90%) as well as a good radical scavenging ability (micromolar range) and metal (M) chelating capacity, with pM (pM = -log[M], CL/CM = 10, CM = 10-6 M at pH = 7.4, M = Fe, Cu, Zn) values close to those of DFP. The most promising compds. have 2-hydroxypropyl linkers, and a selection of compds. have demonstrated neuroprotective roles in neuroblastoma cells treated with Aβ1-42 and ascorbate/iron stressors. Consequently, these hybrids can be considered as attractive multipotent therapeutic mols. that will eventually play key roles against AD progression, namely in the control of cholinergic dysfunction, amyloid peptide aggregation, oxidative stress, and metal modulation, besides presenting a good pharmacokinetic profile.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhsFKqtb3K&md5=08c03fbff71a09f319633f8f710bee8a

        Hiremathad, A.; Chand, K.; Tolayan, L.; Rajeshwari; Keri, R. S.; Esteves, A. R.; Cardoso, S. M.; Chaves, S.; Santos, M. A.         121
        Hydroxypyridinone-benzofuran hybrids with potential protective roles for Alzheimer's disease therapy
        Hiremathad, Asha; Chand, Karam; Tolayan, Lori; Rajeshwari; Keri, Rangappa S.; Esteves, A. Raquel; Cardoso, Sandra M.; Chaves, Silvia; Santos, M. Amelia
        Journal of Inorganic Biochemistry (2018), 179 (), 82-96CODEN: JIBIDJ; ISSN:0162-0134. (Elsevier)
        A series of (3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone)-benzofuran hybrids have been developed and studied as potential multitargeting drugs for Alzheimer's disease (AD). Their design envisaged mainly to mimic the donepezil drug, a marketed inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase (AChE), and to endow the conjugate mols. with extra-properties such as metal chelation, radical scavenging and inhibition of amyloid peptide (Aβ) aggregation. Thus, a set of eleven new hybrid compds. was developed and evaluated for chem. and biol. properties, in soln. and in neuronal cell environment. The results are discussed in terms of the type of substituents on both main moieties and the linker size. The closest similarity with donepezil, in terms of AChE inhibitory activity, was obtained for the O-benzyl-hydroxypyridinone hybrids contg. a 2-methylene linker, although still less active than the drug. However, the free-hydroxypyridinone hybrids present higher activity for the Aβ aggregation inhibition, metal chelating capacity and radical scavenging activity. Overall, some compds. demonstrated capacity to exert a multiple action by hitting three- (7d (N-(2-(3-(benzyloxy)-2-methyl-4-oxopyridin-1(4H)-yl)ethyl)-7-methoxybenzofuran-2-carboxamide)) or four- (8d (N-(2-(3-hydroxy-2-methyl-4-oxopyridin-1(4H)-yl)ethyl)-7-methoxybenzofuran-2-carboxamide), 8f (N-(4-(3-hydroxy-2-methyl-4-oxopyridin-1(4H)-yl)butyl)-7-methoxybenzofuran-2-carboxamide)) pathophysiol. targets of AD. Furthermore, the compds. showed neuroprotective effects in neuronal cells subjected to model stressors of AD, but not significant dependence on the substituent groups. Importantly, the compds. evidenced drug-likeness properties, including good membrane permeability.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhvVOhsr7F&md5=9c2b08a2f02c2e03f1bb525c5e990873

        Mi, Z. S.; Gan, B.; Yu, S. H.; Guo, J. N.; Zhang, C. J.; Jiang, X. Y.; Zhou, T.; Su, J.; Bai, R. R.; Xie, Y. Y.         122
        Dual-target anti-Alzheimer's disease agents with both iron ion chelating and monoamine oxidase-B inhibitory activity
        Mi, Zhisheng; Gan, Bing; Yu, Sihang; Guo, Jianan; Zhang, Changjun; Jiang, Xiaoying; Zhou, Tao; Su, Jing; Bai, Renren; Xie, Yuanyuan
        Journal of Enzyme Inhibition and Medicinal Chemistry (2019), 34 (1), 1489-1497CODEN: JEIMAZ; ISSN:1475-6366. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
        MAO-B leads to an increase in the levels of hydrogen peroxide and oxidative free radicals, which contribute to the etiol. of the AD. Thus, both iron ion chelators and MAO-B inhibitors can be used to treat AD. Taking the coumarin derivs. and hydroxypyridinones as the lead compds., a series of dual-target hybrids were designed and synthesized by Click Chem. The compds. were biol. evaluated for their iron ion chelating and MAO-B inhibitory activity. Most of the compds. displayed excellent iron ion chelating activity and moderate to good anti-MAO-B activity. Compds. and exhibited the most potent MAO-B inhibitory activity, with IC50 values of 0.68 and 0.86 μM, resp. In summary, these dual-target compds. have the potential anti-AD activity.

        Design, synthesis and biological evaluation of hydroxypyridinone-coumarin hybrids as multimodal monoamine oxidase B inhibitors and iron chelates against Alzheimer's disease
        Zhang, Changjun; Yang, Ke; Yu, Sihang; Su, Jing; Yuan, Shengli; Han, Jiaxin; Chen, Yan; Gu, Jinping; Zhou, Tao; Bai, Renren; Xie, Yuanyuan
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2019), 180 (), 367-382CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        Hydroxypyridinone-substituted coumarins I (R1 = H, Me; R2 = H, Me, Et; R3 = H, R4O; R4 = Me, PhCH2, HC≡CCH2, 3-ClC6H4CH2, 3-FC6H4CH2, 4-FC6H4CH2, 3,5-F2C6H3CH2) were prepd. as dual iron chelators and monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitors for potential use in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease. I (R1 = H; R2 = Me; R3 = 3-FC6H4CH2O) (II) exhibited the most potent activity against MAO-B, with an IC50 value of 14.7 nM. II protected U251 cells against oxidative stress and ameliorated murine scopolamine-induced cognitive dysfunction in a model for Alzheimer's disease. Mol. docking calcns. for the binding of II to MAO-B were performed.

        Jiang, X. Y.; Guo, J. N.; Lv, Y. J.; Yao, C. S.; Zhang, C. J.; Mi, Z. S.; Shi, Y.; Gu, J. P.; Zhou, T.; Bai, R. R.; Xie, Y. Y.         [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        124
        Rational design, synthesis and biological evaluation of novel multitargeting anti-AD iron chelators with potent MAO-B inhibitory and antioxidant activity
        Jiang, Xiaoying; Guo, Jianan; Lv, Yangjing; Yao, Chuansheng; Zhang, Changjun; Mi, Zhisheng; Shi, Yuan; Gu, Jinping; Zhou, Tao; Bai, Renren; Xie, Yuanyuan
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2020), 28 (12), 115550CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A series of (3-hydroxypyridin-4-one)-coumarin hybrids I (R1 = H, OMe; R2, R3 = H, Me), II (R1, R3 = H, OH, Me, OMe, OBn; R2 = Me, OEt, 4-F-OBn, etc.) were developed and investigated as potential multitargeting candidates for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease (AD) through the incorporation of iron-chelating and monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibition. This combination endowed the hybrids with good capacity to inhibit MAO-B as well as excellent iron-chelating effects. The pFe3+ values of the compds. were ranging from 16.91 to 20.16, comparable to more potent than the ref. drug deferiprone (DFP). Among them, compd. I (R1 = OMe; R2 = Me; R3 = H) exhibited the most promising activity against MAO-B, with an IC50 value of 87.9 nM. Moreover, compd. I (R1 = OMe; R2 = Me; R3 = H) exerted favorable antioxidant activity, significantly reversed the amyloid-β1-42 (Aβ1-42) induced PC12 cell damage. More importantly, I (R1 = OMe; R2 = Me; R3 = H) remarkably ameliorated the cognitive dysfunction in a scopolamine-induced mice AD model. In brief, a series of hybrids with potential anti-AD effect were successfully obtained, indicating that the design of iron chelators with MAO-B inhibitory and antioxidant activities is an attractive strategy against AD progression.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXhtVWis7bL&md5=5dc324488081d4ce09411efbff7f725b
      125. 125
        Bilitewski, U.; Blodgett, J. A. V.; Duhme-Klair, A. K.; Dallavalle, S.; Laschat, S.; Routledge, A.; Schobert, R. Chemical and biological aspects of nutritional immunity-perspectives for new anti-infectives that target iron uptake systems. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2017, 56 (46), 14360– 14382,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201701586
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        125
        Chemical and Biological Aspects of Nutritional Immunity-Perspectives for New Anti-Infectives that Target Iron Uptake Systems
        Bilitewski, Ursula; Blodgett, Joshua A. V.; Duhme-Klair, Anne-Kathrin; Dallavalle, Sabrina; Laschat, Sabine; Routledge, Anne; Schobert, Rainer
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2017), 56 (46), 14360-14382CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Upon bacterial infection, one of the defense mechanisms of the host is the withdrawal of essential metal ions, in particular iron, which leads to "nutritional immunity". However, bacteria have evolved strategies to overcome iron starvation, for example, by stealing iron from the host or other bacteria through specific iron chelators with high binding affinity. Fortunately, these complex interactions between the host and pathogen that lead to metal homeostasis provide several opportunities for interception and, thus, allow the development of novel antibacterial compds. This Review focuses on iron, discusses recent highlights, and gives some future perspectives which are relevant in the fight against antibiotic resistance.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhs1CntrrP&md5=f7541941c314f5793bca2899708c47e8
      126. 126
        Hider, R. C.; Kong, X. L. Chemistry and biology of siderophores. Nat. Prod. Rep. 2010, 27 (5), 637– 657,  DOI: 10.1039/b906679a
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        126
        Chemistry and biology of siderophores
        Hider, Robert C.; Kong, Xiao-Le
        Natural Product Reports (2010), 27 (5), 637-657CODEN: NPRRDF; ISSN:0265-0568. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Siderophores are compds. produced by bacteria, fungi and graminaceous plants for scavenging iron from the environment. They are low-mol.-wt. compds. (500-1500 daltons) possessing a high affinity for iron(iii) (Kf > 1030), the biosynthesis of which is regulated by iron levels and the function of which is to supply iron to the cell. This article briefly describes the classification and chem. properties of siderophores, before outlining research on siderophore biosynthesis and transport. Clin. important siderophores and the therapeutic potential of siderophore design are described. Appendix 1 provides a comprehensive list of siderophore structures.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXls1Wrsb0%253D&md5=e4e2a8e10cc41de3d7f526b33802b4f7

        Fassihi, A.; Abedi, D.; Saghaie, L.; Sabet, R.; Fazeli, H.; Bostaki, G.; Deilami, O.; Sadinpour, H.         127
        Synthesis, antimicrobial evaluation and QSAR study of some 3-hydroxypyridine-4-one and 3-hydroxypyran-4-one derivatives
        Fassihi, Afshin; Abedi, Daryoush; Saghaie, Lotfollah; Sabet, Razieh; Fazeli, Hossein; Bostaki, Ghasem; Deilami, Omid; Sadinpour, Hekmatollah
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2009), 44 (5), 2145-2157CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        A series of Mannich bases of 2-alkyl-3-hydroxy-pyridine-4-ones were prepd. They were screened for their antibacterial and antifungal activities against a variety of microorganisms using micro plate Alamar Blue assay (MABA) method. Multiple linear regressions (MLR) anal. was performed for the synthesized compds. as well as a series of pyridinone and pyranone derivs. which have been synthesized and evaluated for antimicrobial activity by other researchers previously. Studied compds. showed a better quant. structure-activity relationship (QSAR) model for the antimicrobial activity against Candida albicans and Staphylococcus aureus in comparison with other tested microorganisms.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXjsl2gs70%253D&md5=ee162cf8d85fb7a35ea6727ec2abdbe1
      128. 128
        Sabet, R.; Fassihi, A.; Hemmateenejad, B.; Saghaei, L.; Miri, R.; Gholami, M. Computer-aided design of novel antibacterial 3-hydroxypyridine-4-ones: application of QSAR methods based on the MOLMAP approach. J. Comput.-Aided Mol. Des. 2012, 26 (3), 349– 361,  DOI: 10.1007/s10822-012-9561-2
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        128
        Computer-aided design of novel antibacterial 3-hydroxypyridine-4-ones: application of QSAR methods based on the MOLMAP approach
        Sabet, Razieh; Fassihi, Afshin; Hemmateenejad, Bahram; Saghaei, Lotfollah; Miri, Ramin; Gholami, Maryam
        Journal of Computer-Aided Molecular Design (2012), 26 (3), 349-361CODEN: JCADEQ; ISSN:0920-654X. (Springer)
        3-Hydroxypyridine-4-one derivs. have shown good inhibitory activity against bacterial strains. In this work we report the application of MOLMAP descriptors based on empirical physicochem. properties with genetic algorithm partial least squares (GA-PLS) and counter propagation artificial neural networks (CP-ANN) methods to propose some novel 3-hydroxypyridine-4-one derivs. with improved antibacterial activity against Staphylococcus aureus. A large collection of 302 novel derivs. of this chem. scaffold was selected for this purpose. The activity classes of these compds. were detd. using the two quant. structure activity relationships models. To evaluate the predictability and accuracy of the obtained models, nineteen compds. belonging to all three activity classes were prepd. and the activity of them was detd. against S. aureus. Comparing the exptl. results and the predicted activity classes revealed the accuracy of the obtained models. Seventeen of the nineteen synthesized mols. were correctly predicted by GA-PLS model according to the antimicrobial evaluation method. Mols. 5f and 5h proved to be moderately active and active exptl., but were predicted as inactive and moderately active compds., resp. by this model. The CP-ANN based prediction was correct for sixteen out of the nineteen synthesized mols. 5a, 5h and 5q were moderately active and active based on the antimicrobial assays, but they were introduced as members of inactive, moderately active and inactive classes of compds., resp. according to CP-ANN model.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        129
        Synthesis and characterization of some hydroxypyridone derivatives and their evaluation as antimicrobial agents
        Faidallah, Hassan M.; Rostom, Sherif A. F.; Khan, Khalid A.; Basaif, Salem A.
        Journal of Enzyme Inhibition and Medicinal Chemistry (2013), 28 (5), 926-935CODEN: JEIMAZ; ISSN:1475-6366. (Informa Healthcare)
        The synthesis, in vitro antimicrobial activities of some novel hydroxy pyridines supported with various pharmacophores is described. Twenty-six out of the tested 58 compds. exhibited variable inhibitory effects on the growth of the tested Gram pos. and Gram neg. bacteria. The tested compds. revealed better activity against the Gram pos. rather than the Gram neg. strains. The synthesized hydroxypyridones have shown significant inhibitory effect against Staphylococcus aureus and Bacillus subtilis. Twelve compds. namely; 5d, 5f, 6a, 6b, 8b, 18b, 18c, 19c, 21d, 22b, 22d and 23d were able to produce appreciable growth inhibitory activity against Candida albicans when compared to Clotrimazole. Among these, 22d (I) proved to be the most potent antifungal agent.

        In vitro inhibition of bacterial growth by iron chelators
        Qiu, Di-Hong; Huang, Zhu-Liang; Zhou, Tao; Shen, Chen; Hider, Robert C.
        FEMS Microbiology Letters (2011), 314 (2), 107-111CODEN: FMLED7; ISSN:0378-1097. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        The antimicrobial activity of the iron(III)-selective 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one chelators, CP251(1) and CP252(2), was evaluated in comparison with that of diethylenetriamine-penta acetic acid (3). CP251 was found to exhibit an inhibitory effect on the growth of both Gram-pos. and Gram-neg. bacteria. CP251 may find application in the treatment of external infections such as those assocd. with wounds.

        Synthesis, iron(III)-binding affinity and in vitro evaluation of 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one hexadentate ligands as potential antimicrobial agents

        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2011), 21 (21), 6376-6380CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Iron is a crit. element for the survival of bacteria. Two novel 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one hexadentate ligands with high affinity for iron(III), which disrupt bacterial iron absorption, were designed and synthesized. Biol. studies demonstrate that these two chelators have significant inhibitory effect against both Gram-pos. and Gram-neg. bacteria, and therefore have potential as antimicrobial agents.

        132
        Synthesis, physico-chemical properties, and antimicrobial evaluation of a new series of iron(III) hexadentate chelators
        Xie, Yuan-Yuan; Liu, Mu-Song; Hu, Pan-Pan; Kong, Xiao-Le; Qiu, Di-Hong; Xu, Ji-Lin; Hider, Robert C.; Zhou, Tao
        Medicinal Chemistry Research (2013), 22 (5), 2351-2359CODEN: MCREEB; ISSN:1054-2523. (Birkhaeuser Boston)
        A series of related 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one hexadentate ligands I (R = H, Me, n-hexyl, CH2CH2OH, etc.) have been synthesized. These chelators were found to possess a high affinity for iron(III), with a pFe value of about 30. As iron is a crit. element to the survival of bacteria, these chelators were predicted to inhibit the growth of bacteria by disrupting bacterial iron absorption. Indeed, they were demonstrated to possess appreciable inhibitory activity against both Gram-pos. and Gram-neg. bacteria, and therefore, they have potential as antimicrobial agents. I (R = Et, CH2CH2OMe) were found to be particularly effective against Gram-neg. species.

        Zhu, C. F.; Qiu, D. H.; Kong, X. L.; Hider, R. C.; Zhou, T. Synthesis and in-vitro antimicrobial evaluation of a high-affinity iron chelator in combination with chloramphenicol. J. Pharm. Pharmacol. 2013, 65 (4), 512– 520,  DOI: 10.1111/jphp.12013

        133
        Synthesis and in-vitro antimicrobial evaluation of a high-affinity iron chelator in combination with chloramphenicol
        Zhu, Chun-Feng; Qiu, Di-Hong; Kong, Xiao-Le; Hider, Robert C.; Zhou, Tao
        Journal of Pharmacy and Pharmacology (2013), 65 (4), 512-520CODEN: JPPMAB; ISSN:0022-3573. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
        The objectives of this study were first to design and synthesize a hexadentate chelator with high iron(III) affinity and, second, to evaluate its antimicrobial activity in the presence and absence of chloramphenicol. A hexadentate ligand was synthesized by conjugating a protected bidentate compd. onto a tripodal structure. The pKa values and iron affinity of the chelator were detd. by spectrophotometric titrn. Min. inhibitory concns. were detd. by visual inspection of broth turbidity. The bactericidal rates were calcd. by counting the colony nos. on a light board after incubation with and without an antimicrobial agent. A hexadentate 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one was found to possess a high affinity for iron(III), with a pFe value of 31.2 (neg. logarithm of concn. of the free iron(III) in soln. (when [Fe3+]Total = 10-6 M; [Ligand]Total = 10-5 M; pH = 7.4). We found that this chelator had an appreciable inhibitory effect in vitro against the two bacterial strains Providencia stuartii and Staphylococcus aureus, particularly in the presence of chloramphenicol. A 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one hexadentate ligand has potential as an antimicrobial agent. Combination therapy with this iron chelator plus chloramphenicol has potential for the treatment of extracellular infections.

        134
        Design, Synthesis, and Antimicrobial Evaluation of Hexadentate Hydroxypyridinones with High Iron(III) Affinity
        Zhang, Ming-Xia; Zhu, Chun-Feng; Zhou, Ying-Jun; Kong, Xiao-Le; Hider, Robert C.; Zhou, Tao
        Chemical Biology & Drug Design (2014), 84 (6), 659-668CODEN: CBDDAL; ISSN:1747-0277. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        A range of hexadentate 3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone derivs. (HPOs) with a high affinity for iron(III) has been synthesized. The log stability consts. of two HPO-iron complexes (logK1) were detd. to be over 34 and pFe values of the two HPOs were detd. to be over 31. An antimicrobial assay indicated that they are able to markedly inhibit the growth of both Gram-pos. and Gram-neg. bacteria. Two compds. were found to exhibit the strongest inhibitory activity against Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus subtilis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli with MIC values of 8, 8, 16, 8 μg/mL, resp. These results indicate that hexadentate 3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone derivs. have potential application as antimicrobial agents, esp. in the treatment of wound infection. The synthesis of the target compds. was achieved using N-[4-amino-7-[[(1,1-dimethylethoxy)carbonyl]amino]-4-[3-[[(1,1-dimethylethoxy)carbonyl]amino]propyl]heptyl]carbamic acid 1,1-dimethylethyl ester and butanoyl chloride and N-[(phenylmethoxy)carbonyl]--L-leucine as reactants.

        Novel 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one hexadentate ligand-based polymeric iron chelator: synthesis, characterization and antimicrobial evaluation
        Zhou, Ying-Jun; Kong, Xiao-Le; Li, Jun-Pei; Ma, Yong-Min; Hider, Robert C.; Zhou, Tao
        MedChemComm (2015), 6 (9), 1620-1625CODEN: MCCEAY; ISSN:2040-2503. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A novel 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one (HPO) hexadentate monomeric chelator 14 has been synthesized and incorporated into polymers by copolymn. with 2-hydroxyethyl acrylate (HEA), using azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as an initiator. The monomeric chelator was found to possess very high affinity for iron(III), with the log stability const. of the iron complex (log K1) = 33.61 and pFe3+ = 30.37. The iron binding capacity and monomer recovery of the copolymers were detd. using spectrophotometry. The in vitro antimicrobial activity of monomeric chelator 14 and polymeric chelator 16-4 against both Gram-pos. bacteria (Staphylococcus aureus and Bacillus subtilis) and Gram-neg. bacteria (Escherichia coli, Salmonella spp., and Pseudomonas aeruginosa) was evaluated by inhibition zone and min. inhibitory concn. (MIC) assays, which demonstrated that both monomeric and polymeric chelators possess inhibitory activity. The polymeric chelators possess potential application for the treatment of wound infection.

        136
        Hexadentate 3-hydroxypyridin-4-ones with high iron(III) affinity: Design, synthesis and inhibition on methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas strains
        Zhou, Ying-Jun; Liu, Mu-Song; Osamah, Al Rugaie; Kong, Xiao-Le; Alsam, Selwa; Battah, Sinan; Xie, Yuan-Yuan; Hider, Robert C.; Zhou, Tao
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2015), 94 (), 8-21CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        A range of hexadentate 3-hydroxypyridin-4-ones (I; R, R1 = alkyl, alkoxyalkyl) have been synthesized. These compds. were found to possess a high affinity for iron(III), with logK1 values of about 34 and pFe values over 30. Antimicrobial assays indicated that they can inhibit the growth of three clin. isolates of methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and three clin. isolates of Pseudomonas, suggesting that hexadentate 3-hydroxypyridin-4-ones have potential application in the treatment of wound infections.

      137. 137
        Fernandes, S. S.; Nunes, A.; Gomes, A. R.; de Castro, B.; Hider, R. C.; Rangel, M.; Appelberg, R.; Gomes, M. S. Identification of a new hexadentate iron chelator capable of restricting the intramacrophagic growth of Mycobacterium avium. Microbes Infect. 2010, 12 (4), 287– 294,  DOI: 10.1016/j.micinf.2010.01.003
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        137
        Identification of a new hexadentate iron chelator capable of restricting the intramacrophagic growth of Mycobacterium avium
        Fernandes, Sofia Sousa; Nunes, Ana; Gomes, Ana Rita; de Castro, Baltazar; Hider, Robert C.; Rangel, Maria; Appelberg, Rui; Gomes, Maria Salome
        Microbes and Infection (2010), 12 (4), 287-294CODEN: MCINFS; ISSN:1286-4579. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        Iron accumulation has been suggested to contribute to an increase of the susceptibility to mycobacterial infections. In this study we tested the effect of an array of iron chelating ligands of the 3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone family, in the intramacrophagic growth of Mycobacterium avium. We found that bidentate chelators, namely N-alkyl-3-hydroxy-4-pyridinones and N-aryl-3-hydroxy-4-pyridinones, did not affect the growth of M. avium inside mouse macrophages. In the case of the hexadentate chelators, those synthesized using an alkylamine (CP262) or a benzene ring (CP252) to link the three bidentate units, did not have an inhibitory effect on intramacrophagic growth of M. avium while those synthesized from a tripodal structure to anchor the bidentate units were capable of inhibiting the intramacrophagic growth of M. avium. The mol. we designated CP777 had the strongest inhibitory activity. The growth-reducing activity of CP777 was abrogated when this mol. was satd. with iron. These results confirm that iron deprivation, by the use of iron chelating compds., restricts M. avium growth and that new iron chelators offer an approach to controlling mycobacterial infections.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjtFynsr4%253D&md5=9f24a4512c992a329197e125e145b5e4
      138. 138
        Nunes, A.; Podinovskaia, M.; Leite, A.; Gameiro, P.; Zhou, T.; Ma, Y.; Kong, X.; Schaible, U. E.; Hider, R. C.; Rangel, M. Fluorescent 3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone hexadentate iron chelators: intracellular distribution and the relevance to antimycobacterial properties. JBIC, J. Biol. Inorg. Chem. 2010, 15 (6), 861– 877,  DOI: 10.1007/s00775-010-0650-1
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        138
        Fluorescent 3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone hexadentate iron chelators: intracellular distribution and the relevance to antimycobacterial properties
        Nunes, Ana; Podinovskaia, Maria; Leite, Andreia; Gameiro, Paula; Zhou, Tao; Ma, Yongmin; Kong, Xiaole; Schaible, Ulrich E.; Hider, Robert C.; Rangel, Maria
        JBIC, Journal of Biological Inorganic Chemistry (2010), 15 (6), 861-877CODEN: JJBCFA; ISSN:0949-8257. (Springer)
        Abstr.: We report the synthesis and characterization of a fluorescent iron chelator (4), shown to be effective in inhibiting the growth of Mycobacterium avium in macrophages, together with the synthesis and characterization of two unsuccessful analogs selected to facilitate identification of the mol. properties responsible for the antimicrobial activity. Partition of the chelators in liposomes was investigated and the compds. were assessed with respect to uptake by macrophages, responsiveness to iron overload/iron deprivation and intracellular distribution by flow cytometry and confocal microscopy. The synthesis of the hexadentate chelators is based on a tetrahedral structure to which three bidentate 3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone chelating units are linked via amide bonds. The structure is synthetically versatile, allowing further addn. of functional groups such as fluorophores. Here, we analyze the non-functionalized hexadentate unit (3) and the corresponding rhodamine B (4) and fluorescein (5) labeled chelators. The iron(III) stability const. was detd. for 3 and the values log β = 34.4 and pFe3+ = 29.8 indicate an affinity for iron of the same order of magnitude as that of mycobacteria siderophores. Fluorescence properties in the presence of liposomes show that 4 strongly interacts with the lipid phase, whereas 5 does not. Such different behavior may explain their distinct intracellular localization as revealed by confocal microscopy. The flow cytometry and confocal microscopy studies indicate that 4 is readily engulfed by macrophages and targeted to cytosol and vesicles of the endolysosomal continuum, whereas 5 is differentially distributed and only partially colocalizes with 4 after prolonged incubation. Differential distribution of the compds. is likely to account for their different efficacy against mycobacteria.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXkt1aqtbk%253D&md5=bab314f755a7aab465d892f97d9b6d18
      139. 139
        Moniz, T.; Feio, M.; Silva, D.; de Castro, B.; Rangel, M. Study of the effect of thiourea and N-ethyl groups on antibacterial activity of rhodamine-labeled 3,4-HPO iron chelators against Gram (±) bacteria. Med. Chem. Res. 2018, 27 (5), 1472– 1477,  DOI: 10.1007/s00044-018-2165-1
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        139
        Study of the effect of thiourea and N-ethyl groups on antibacterial activity of rhodamine-labeled 3,4-HPO iron chelators against Gram (+/-) bacteria
        Moniz, Tania; Feio, Maria; Silva, Daniel; de Castro, Baltazar; Rangel, Maria
        Medicinal Chemistry Research (2018), 27 (5), 1472-1477CODEN: MCREEB; ISSN:1054-2523. (Springer)
        In the sequence of the work in which we identified functional groups of rhodamine labeled 3,4-HPO chelators that are crucial for their activity against Mycobacterium avium infection we now scrutinize if the same groups are also relevant for the chelators antibacterial activity against Gram (+/-) bacteria. In this new infection scenario, we confirmed that a thiourea linkage and N-Et substituents on the xanthene ring are important and there is an advantage of the assocn. of both groups in the mol. framework. In particular, we found that three hexadentate chelators (MRH7, MRH8, and MRH10) inhibit bacterial growth of Staphylococcus (S). aureus ATCC 25923 and S. epidermis ATCC 12228 and one hexadentate chelator (MRH7) also inhibits the growth of Escherichia (E.) coli ATCC 25922.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXktlGqtLk%253D&md5=6f52b6f2f90305fb023e6d46f457a643
      140. 140
        Novais, A.; Moniz, T.; Rebelo, A. R.; Silva, A. M. G.; Rangel, M.; Peixe, L. New fluorescent rosamine chelator showing promising antibacterial activity against Gram-positive bacteria. Bioorg. Chem. 2018, 79, 341– 349,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bioorg.2018.05.013
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        140
        New fluorescent rosamine chelator showing promising antibacterial activity against Gram-positive bacteria
        Novais, Angela; Moniz, Tania; Rebelo, Ana Rita; Silva, Ana M. G.; Rangel, Maria; Peixe, Luisa
        Bioorganic Chemistry (2018), 79 (), 341-349CODEN: BOCMBM; ISSN:0045-2068. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The restricted no. of antibiotics to treat infections caused by common multidrug resistant bacterial pathogens in the clin. setting demands a continuous search for new mols. with antibacterial properties. Bacterial iron deprivation represents a promising alternative, being iron chelators an attractive class for drug design in which particular compds. seem to have antibacterial effect. In this work, we report the synthesis and characterization of a new fluorescent 3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone (3,4-HPO) iron chelator functionalized with a carboxyrosamine fluorophore (MRB20). The antibacterial activity of MRB20 was assessed against representative strains from clin. relevant Gram-pos. and Gram-neg. bacterial species and further compared with the inhibitory effect of a set of structurally related iron chelators including Deferiprone (1,2-dimethyl-3-hydroxy-4-pyridinone). Compds. exhibiting a promising minimal inhibitory concn. (MIC<10mg/L) were further tested against a wider range of bacterial genera and species (Staphylococcus spp. Enterococcus spp. Listeria monocytogenes, Bacillus spp.), including multidrug resistant bacteria. With the exception of the novel compd. (MRB20), all chelators inhibited the strains assayed at very high concns. [min. inhibitory concns. (MIC) ranging from 70mg/L to >180mg/L]. MRB20 revealed a good antibacterial activity (6.7-13.2mg/L) against Gram-pos. strains from different genera and species, including clin. relevant species (Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, Enterococcus faecium, Enterococcus faecalis), which might be eventually compatible with a therapeutic application or as adjuvant.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtVamsrfJ&md5=e9ac7991af1fb4bef523280e64fe9607
      141. 141
        Dhal, P. K.; Polomoscanik, S. C.; Avila, L. Z.; Holmes-Farley, S. R.; Miller, R. J. Functional polymers as therapeutic agents: concept to market place. Adv. Drug Delivery Rev. 2009, 61 (13), 1121– 1130,  DOI: 10.1016/j.addr.2009.05.004
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        141
        Functional polymers as therapeutic agents: Concept to market place
        Dhal, Pradeep K.; Polomoscanik, Steven C.; Avila, Louis Z.; Holmes-Farley, S. Randall; Miller, Robert J.
        Advanced Drug Delivery Reviews (2009), 61 (13), 1121-1130CODEN: ADDREP; ISSN:0169-409X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Biol. active synthetic polymers have received considerable scientific interest and attention in recent years for their potential as promising novel therapeutic agents to treat human diseases. Although a significant amt. of research has been carried out involving polymer-linked drugs as targeted and sustained release drug delivery systems and prodrugs, examples on bioactive polymers that exhibit intrinsic therapeutic properties are relatively less. Several appealing characteristics of synthetic polymers including high mol. wt., mol. architecture, and controlled polydispersity can all be utilized to discover a new generation of therapies. For example, high mol. wt. bioactive polymers can be restricted to gastrointestinal tract, where they can selectively recognize, bind, and remove target disease causing substances from the body. The appealing features of GI tract restriction and stability in biol. environment render these polymeric drugs to be devoid of systemic toxicity that are generally assocd. with small mol. systemic drugs. The present article highlights recent developments in the rational design and synthesis of appropriate functional polymers that have resulted in a no. of promising polymer based therapies and biomaterials, including some marketed products.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtlWht7fJ&md5=67b98d7c4d52f7fb0b112d5fd1871814
      142. 142
        Feng, M. H.; Vanderdoes, L.; Bantjes, A. Iron(III)-chelating resins. 3. synthesis, iron(III)-chelating properties, and in-vitro antibacterial activity of compounds containing 3-hydroxy-2-methyl-4(1H)-pyridinone ligands. J. Med. Chem. 1993, 36 (19), 2822– 2827,  DOI: 10.1021/jm00071a013
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        142
        Iron(III)-chelating resins. 3. Synthesis, iron(III)-chelating properties, and in vitro antibacterial activity of compounds containing 3-hydroxy-2-methyl-4(1H)-pyridinone ligands
        Feng, Min Hua; van der Does, Leen; Bantjes, Adriaan
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (1993), 36 (19), 2822-7CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623.
        The synthesis, iron(III)-chelating properties, and antibacterial activity of several compds. contg. the 3-hydroxy-2-methyl-4(1H)-pyridinone (HMP) moiety are described. Using the HMP derivs., iron(III) could be mobilized from iron(III)-binding proteins at physiol. pH with a rate order of transferrin > lactoferrin > ferritin. Addn. of HMP-contg. compds. to a growth medium at a concn. of 20 mM/L resulted in a complete inhibition of the growth of Escherichia coli and about 90% inhibition for Listeria inocua after 7 h of incubation at 37 °C. After inhibition of bacteria growth by the HMP derivs., growth started again when ferric ions were added to the medium, which implies that the antibacterial activity is due to a limitation of iron available to the organisms.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3sXlsFKjsLg%253D&md5=bb48168ab601c31942907e798617b027
      143. 143
        Feng, M. H.; Vanderdoes, L.; Bantjes, A. Iron(III)-chelating resins. IX. antibacterial activity of a water-insoluble iron(III)-chelating resin. J. Med. Chem. 1994, 37 (7), 924– 927,  DOI: 10.1021/jm00033a009
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        143
        Iron(III)-Chelating Resins. IX. Antibacterial Activity of a Water-Insoluble Iron(III)-Chelating Resin
        Feng, Minhua; van der Does, Leen; Bantjes, Adriaan
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (1994), 37 (7), 924-7CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623.
        Antibacterial activity of a water-insol. iron(III)-chelating resin with covalently bonded 3-hydroxy-2-methyl-4(1H)-pyridinone (HMP) groups was evaluated in a brain heart infusion (BHI) medium. The activity of the resin against Escherichia coli was lower than that of sol. HMP iron(III) chelators, whereas against Listeria inocua, an activity approx. equal to those of the sol. chelators was found. It was obsd. that the growth of E. coli and L. inocua was reduced by increasing the amts. of the resin from 2 to 40 mg of resin/mL of medium. Inhibition of bacterial growth in the presence of the resin (10 mg/mL) was abolished by addn. of ferric ion to the medium, indicating that the growth of E. coli and L. inocua was dependent on the available iron in the medium. Reducing the iron concn. in the medium from 14.2 to 0.16 μM (by action of the resin) resulted in a decrease in the growth response from 100% to 19% for E. coli and from 100% to 10% for L. inocua. In addn., the influence of citrate was studied, but only small effects of citrate supplementation on the growth of bacteria and on the antibacterial activity of the resin were obsd.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        144
        Macromolecular iron-chelators via RAFT-polymerization for the inhibition of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus growth
        Li, Junpei; Olaleye, Eniola D.; Kong, Xiaole; Zhou, Tao; Ma, Yongmin; Jurach, Jagoda; Al Rugaie, Osamah; Hider, Robert C.; Zhang, Guoqing; Alsam, Selwa; Abbate, Vincenzo
        Polymer (2016), 87 (), 64-72CODEN: POLMAG; ISSN:0032-3861. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A series of linear poly (glycidyl methacrylate) (PGMA) polymers were synthesized via RAFT polymn. and conjugated with amine-contg. 3-hydroxypyridin-4-ones (HPOs) to generate a panel of HPO-contg. materials with controlled structures and specific iron-binding functions. The structures of the resulting polymers were characterized via 1H NMR, GPC and FT-IR and their chelating capacity for iron was investigated using UV-Vis spectrophotometric titrn. of the iron(III) complexes. In vitro antimicrobial studies of selected ligand-contg. homopolymers demonstrate that the homopolymers are capable of inhibiting the growth of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It is proposed that the inhibition activity of MRSA is derived from the iron-chelating capability of the iron-binding polymers.

        145
        In vitro antimicrobial activity of hydroxypyridinone hexadentate-based dendrimeric chelators alone and in combination with norfloxacin
        Zhou, Ying-Jun; Zhang, Ming-Xia; Hider, Robert C.; Zhou, Tao
        FEMS Microbiology Letters (2014), 355 (2), 124-130CODEN: FMLED7; ISSN:0378-1097. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        The antimicrobial activity of one 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one (HPO) hexadentate (1) and three HPO hexadentate-based dendrimeric chelators (2-4) was evaluated. They were found to exhibit marked inhibitory effect on the growth of two Gram-pos. bacteria and two Gram-neg. bacteria. The combination treatment of dendrimeric chelator 2 with norfloxacin against Staphyloccocus aureus and Escherichia coli showed a dramatic synergistic bactericidal effect. As the dendrimeric chelator has a large mol. wt., its combination with norfloxacin may find application in the treatment of external infections.

        Zhou, T.; Chen, K.; Kong, L. M.; Liu, M. S.; Ma, Y. M.; Xie, Y. Y.; Hider, R. C. Synthesis, iron binding and antimicrobial properties of hexadentate 3-hydroxypyridinones-terminated dendrimers. Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2018, 28 (14), 2504– 2512,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmcl.2018.05.058

        146
        Synthesis, iron binding and antimicrobial properties of hexadentate 3-hydroxypyridinones-terminated dendrimers
        Zhou, Tao; Chen, Kai; Kong, Li-Min; Liu, Mu-Song; Ma, Yong-Min; Xie, Yuan-Yuan; Hider, Robert C.
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2018), 28 (14), 2504-2512CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Macromol. chelators have potential applications in the medical area, for instance, in treatment of iron overload-related disorders and in the treatment of external infections. In this investigation, several novel iron(III)-selective hydroxypyridinone hexadentate-terminated first and second generation dendrimeric chelators were synthesized using a convergent strategy. Their iron chelating ability was demonstrated by UV/Visible spectrometry and high resoln. mass spectrometry (HRMS). The iron binding affinities were also investigated by the competition with a fluorescent iron chelator CP691. The result indicated that these dendrimers possesses a high affinity for iron with a very high pFe3+ value, which is close to that of an isolated hexadentate unit. These dendrimeric chelators were found to exhibit inhibitory effect on the growth of both Gram-pos. and Gram-neg. bacteria.

        Ang, M. T. C.; Gumbau-Brisa, R.; Allan, D. S.; McDonald, R.; Ferguson, M. J.; Holbein, B. E.; Bierenstiel, M. DIBI, a 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one chelator iron-binding polymer with enhanced antimicrobial activity. MedChemComm 2018, 9 (7), 1206– 1212,  DOI: 10.1039/C8MD00192H
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        147
        DIBI, a 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one chelator iron-binding polymer with enhanced antimicrobial activity
        Ang, M. Trisha C.; Gumbau-Brisa, Roger; Allan, David S.; McDonald, Robert; Ferguson, Michael J.; Holbein, Bruce E.; Bierenstiel, Matthias
        MedChemComm (2018), 9 (7), 1206-1212CODEN: MCCEAY; ISSN:2040-2503. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Depriving microorganisms of bioavailable iron is a promising strategy for new anti-infective agents. The new, highly water-sol., low mol. wt. co-polymer DIBI was developed to selectively bind iron(III) ions as a tris chelate and acts as a standalone anti-infective. Min. inhibitory concn. (MIC) studies show DIBI is effective against representative ref. strains for Gram-pos. and Gram-neg. bacteria S. aureus and A. baumannii, and the fungus C. albicans. Compared to the small mol. iron chelators, deferiprone and deferoxamine, DIBI outclassed these by factors of 100 to 1000 for inhibition of initial growth. DIBI and a series of related co-polymers (Mw of 2-9 kDa) were synthesized via reversible addn.-fragmentation chain transfer (RAFT) polymn. of a chelating 3-hydroxypyridin-4-one (HPO) methacrylamide monomer and N-vinylpyrrolidone (NVP). Full incorporation of the HPO monomer into the co-polymers from the reaction soln. was detd. by 1H NMR spectroscopy and ranged from 4.6 to 25.6 mol%. UV-vis spectroscopy showed that all the HPO in DIBI binds readily to iron(III) in a tris chelate mode to the max. theor. iron(III) binding capacity of the co-polymer. Chem. characterization including single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses of the O-benzyl protected and the functional HPO monomer are discussed. By design, DIBI is highly water sol.; the highest mass fraction in water tested was 70% wt./wt., without the need of org. co-solvents.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtFCmtLvM&md5=7fbf6b641592fe2624535978ad990712
      148. 148
        Parquet, M. D. C.; Savage, K. A.; Allan, D. S.; Davidson, R. J.; Holbein, B. E. Novel iron-chelator DIBI inhibits staphylococcus aureus growth, suppresses experimental MRSA infection in mice and enhances the activities of diverse antibiotics in vitro. Front. Microbiol. 2018, 9, 1811– 1821,  DOI: 10.3389/fmicb.2018.01811
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        148
        Novel Iron-Chelator DIBI Inhibits Staphylococcus aureus Growth, Suppresses Experimental MRSA Infection in Mice and Enhances the Activities of Diverse Antibiotics in vitro
        Parquet Maria Del Carmen; Savage Kimberley A; Allan David S; Holbein Bruce E; Davidson Ross J; Holbein Bruce E; Davidson Ross J
        Frontiers in microbiology (2018), 9 (), 1811 ISSN:1664-302X.
        DIBI, a purpose-designed hydroxypyridinone-containing iron-chelating antimicrobial polymer was studied for its anti-staphylococcal activities in vitro in comparison to deferiprone, the chemically related, small molecule hydroxypyridinone chelator. The sensitivities of 18 clinical isolates of Staphylococcus aureus from human, canine and bovine infections were determined. DIBI was strongly inhibitory to all isolates, displaying approximately 100-fold more inhibitory activity than deferiprone when compared on their molar iron-binding capacities. Sensitivity to DIBI was similar for both antibiotic-resistant and -sensitive isolates, including hospital- and community-acquired (United States 300) MRSA. DIBI inhibition was primarily bacteriostatic in nature at low concentration and was reversible by addition of Fe. DIBI also exhibited in vivo anti-infective activity in two distinct MRSA ATCC43300 infection and colonization models in mice. In a superficial skin wound infection model, topical application of DIBI provided a dose-dependent suppression of infection along with reduced wound inflammation. Intranasal DIBI reduced staphylococcal burden by >2 log in a MRSA nares carriage model. DIBI was also examined for its influence on antibiotic activities with a reference isolate ATCC6538, typically utilized to assess new antimicrobials. Sub-bacteriostatic concentrations of DIBI resulted in Fe-restricted growth and this physiological condition displayed increased sensitivity to GEN, CIP, and VAN. DIBI did not impair antibiotic activity but rather it enhanced overall killing. Importantly, recovery growth of survivors that typically followed an initial sub-MIC antibiotic killing phase was substantially suppressed by DIBI for each of the antibiotics examined. DIBI has promise for restricting staphylococcal infection on its own, regardless of the isolate's animal source or antibiotic resistance profile. DIBI also has potential for use in combination with various classes of currently available antibiotics to improve their responses.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB3c3islyisQ%253D%253D&md5=84e201118675b8bfccd6595a7a0647af

        Murphy-Benenato, K. E.; Bhagunde, P. R.; Chen, A.; Davis, H. E.; Durand-Reville, T. F.; Ehmann, D. E.; Galullo, V.; Harris, J. J.; Hatoum-Mokdad, H.; Jahic, H.; Kim, A.; Manjunatha, M. R.; Manyak, E. L.; Mueller, J.; Patey, S.; Quiroga, O.; Rooney, M.; Sha, L.; Shapiro, A. B.; Sylvester, M.; Tan, B.; Tsai, A. S.; Uria-Nickelsen, M.; Wu, Y.; Zambrowski, M.; Zhao, S. X.
